description.en:
<html>Sinan Aga Fountain has a quadrangular plan. The part of the historical fountain with three faces facing the mosque is deaf. The fountain is built entirely of cut stone material. It has a stone roof with pyramidal properties. Dr. Rifat Osman ,as with many other buildings in the city, conveys a lot of information about Sinan Aga Fountain. According to the information given by him, the fountain is fed from the sources in the vineyards located on the side of the AynalÄ± Tabya(mirrored bastion). This source also gives water to the numerous fountains located in the city.

Apart from Dr.Rifat Osman, Badi Efendi, a historian from Edirne, is one of the names who gives a lot of information about this place. Accordingly, the fountain is said to be built on 19 August 1310. The name,Sinan Aga, is not the first person to bring water to the city, his name has been recorded specifically as having repaired this fountain. On the corners facing the street side of the fountain, there are columns with hourglass-shaped pedestals. Above all three facades,there  is a pointed arch keystone.

Sinan Aga Fountain has a height of 5 meters and 75 cm. A mirror Stone is placed in the niche of the historical fountain, which is around four meters in width. At the focal point of the mirror Stone is the sliced deaf arch. At the bottom of the arch, there are holes in the pipe known as the pipe with no tap. A rectangular panel at the top of the fountain was left empty. The water trough on the western side is invisible due to the road passing through it.

There is an original inscription on the key part of the pointed arch of Sinan Aga Fountain. The rumis on the border below the eaves cover the interior of the fountain in a horizontal form. There are also badges on top of the keystones on each facade. The eastern part of the fountain has a brow-arched structure. Tulip motifs are prominent in the triangles in this section.
</html>
description.de:
Der Sinan AÄŸa Brunnen hat einen rechteckigen Grundriss. Der Teil des historischen Brunnens, der drei Seiten hat und der Moschee zugewandt ist, ist taub. Der Brunnen besteht vollstÃ¤ndig aus geschnittenem Steinmaterial. Es hat ein pyramidenfÃ¶rmiges Steindach. Dr. RÄ±fat Osman vermittelt viele Informationen Ã¼ber den Sinan AÄŸa-Brunnen, wie in vielen anderen GebÃ¤uden der Stadt. Nach seinen Angaben wird der Brunnen aus den Quellen der Weinberge auf der Seite von AynalÄ± Tabya gespeist. Diese Quelle gibt auch vielen Brunnen in der Stadt Wasser.

Edirnes Historiker Badi Efendi ist neben Dr. RÄ±fat Osman einer der Namen, die viele Informationen Ã¼ber diesen Ort lieferten. Dementsprechend soll der Brunnen am 19. August 1310 gebaut worden sein. Der Name Sinan AÄŸa ist nicht der erste, der Wasser in die Stadt bringt. Er wurde in speziellen Aufzeichnungen festgehalten, weil er diesen Brunnen repariert hat. An den zur StraÃŸe gerichteten Ecken des Brunnens befinden sich SÃ¤ulen mit Sockeln in Sanduhrform. An allen drei Fassaden befindet sich ein Spitzbogen.

Die HÃ¶he des Sinan AÄŸa Brunnens vom Boden betrÃ¤gt 5,75 Meter. In der rund vier Meter breiten Nische des historischen Brunnens befindet sich ein Spiegelstein. Im Mittelpunkt des Spiegelsteins steht ein segmentierter Taubbogen. Am Boden des Bogens befinden sich DÃ¼senlÃ¶cher, die als Rohr bezeichnet werden, durch das Wasser flieÃŸt und am Ende kein Wasserhahn vorhanden ist. Der  Brunnen, der oben eine rechteckige Platte hat, bleibt leer. Der Wassertrog im westlichen Teil ist aufgrund der dort vorbeifahrenden StraÃŸe nicht sichtbar.

Auf dem Schlossteil des scharfen Bogens des Sinan AÄŸa-Brunnens befindet sich eine Originalinschrift. Die Rumis an der Grenze unter der Traufe umgeben das Innere des Brunnens horizontal. Es gibt auch Rosetten auf den Schlusssteinen an jeder Fassade. Der Ã¶stliche Teil des Brunnens hat eine gewÃ¶lbte Struktur. Tulpenmotive stechen in diesem Abschnitt in den Dreiecken hervor.

description.en:
The Ataturk House Museum, where the erzurum congress, one of the most important steps of the War of Independence, is carried out, tells the story of the liberation of The Land of Turkey.

It was built as a mansion in the 19th century by a wealthy man from Erzurum and later donated to the state. Between 1915 and 1916, the mansion was used as the German Consulate for as little as nine months and later became the residence address of the Governor's Office. The governor at the time, Mahir Akkaya, lived here until July 3, 1919, and then left the city and the mansion was evacuated.

On 9th July, 1919, Hussein Rauf Bey and his friends settled the mansion for preperation of the Erzurum Congress, one of the most important preparatory processes of the War of Independence. For the liberation of the country, the mansion gained a historical importance with the struggles of the soldiers who fought tooth and nail for 52 days. When headteacher Gazi Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk left the city after Erzurum congress, the building begins to be used as 'Governor's Mansion'.

AtatÃ¼rk established the State of the Republic of Turkey on 29th of October 1923, on the territory of the country that was won after the War of Independence. On his first visit to Erzurum after the establishment of the Republic, Mustafa Kemal Pasha was given a gift on behalf of Erzurum, the golden key of the city, was  built in a jewelry store and the deed of the city by Nazif Bey, the major of time . 

In between 1930-34, the mansion was given to the commanders of the Erzurum Corps Command then made over to his sister Makbule Boysan after AtatÃ¼rk's death. The building, which was transferred to the Child Protection Agency with the request of Makbule HanÄ±m, serves to protect motherless and fatherless children until 1980. Finally, the mansion was transferred to the Ministry of Culture by the Ministry of Health in 1984 and opened to the serve of public as AtatÃ¼rk House Museum in the same year.
description.de:
Das Museum des Hauses von AtatÃ¼rk ist einer der wichtigsten Schritte des UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitskrieges und der Ort wo die Versammlungen des Erzurum Kongresses durchgefÃ¼hrt wurde. Es erzÃ¤hlt die Geschichte der Befreiung der TÃ¼rkei.
Es wurde im 19. Jahrhundert von einem reichen Mann aus Erzurum als Herberge erbaut und spÃ¤ter an den Staat gespendet. Die Herberge, das zwischen 1915 und 1916 neun Monate lang als Deutsches Konsulat diente, wurde spÃ¤ter die Residenzadresse des Gouverneurs. Der damalige Gouverneur Mahir Akkaya lebte hier bis zum 3. Juli 1919 und verlieÃŸ dann die Stadt und die Herberge wurde evakuiert.

HÃ¼seyin Rauf Bey und seine Freunde richten sich fÃ¼r die Vorbereitungen des Erzurum-Kongresses, einer der wichtigsten Vorbereitungen fÃ¼r den UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitskrieg am 9. Juli 1919 in die Herberge ein. FÃ¼r 52 Tage zur Befreiung des Landes erlangt die Herberge mit den BemÃ¼hungen der Soldaten, die ihr alles dafÃ¼r gaben, historische Bedeutung. Als der Oberlehrer (der als erster Lehrer der TÃ¼rkei genannt wird) Gazi Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk nach dem Erzurum-Kongress die Stadt verlieÃŸ, wurde das GebÃ¤ude als "Gouverneursherberge" genutzt.

AtatÃ¼rk grÃ¼ndet nach dem Gewann des UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitskrieges  am 29.Oktober 1923 den Staat die TÃ¼rkische Republik. Beim ersten Besuch in Erzurum nach der GrÃ¼ndung der Republik wurden der goldene SchlÃ¼ssel und die Urkunde der Stadt, die von einem Juwelier von Nazif Bey angefertigt wurden, Mustafa Kemal Pascha im Auftrag von Erzurum Ã¼berreicht.

Die Herberge, das 1930/34 den Kommandeuren des Erzurum-Korps Ã¼bergeben wurde, ging nach dem Tod von AtatÃ¼rk an seine Schwester Makbule Boysan Ã¼ber. Das GebÃ¤ude, das auf Wunsch von Makbule HanÄ±m an die KinderschutzbehÃ¶rde Ã¼bergeben wurde, dient bis 1980 dem Schutz von Waisenkindern. SchlieÃŸlich wird die Herberge, die 1984 vom Gesundheitsministerium an das Kulturministerium Ã¼bergeben wurde, im selben Jahr Museum des Hauses von AtatÃ¼rk der Ã–ffentlichkeit zugÃ¤nglich gemacht.

description.en:
<html>One of the most important points of GÃ¶kÃ§eada is the Port of Kuzu. Located in the northeastern part of the island in the Aegean Sea, the port can be reached by small-sized vessels as well as large-sized ones. In addition, passengers arriving by fast ferry from Ã‡anakkale come to this port. GÃ¶kÃ§eada-Kabatepe flights are also being carried out. In summary, the island's connection to other geographies is through the Port of Kuzu.

Lamb Harbour, which features a transfer centre, is also a filming area for the surrounding area. The beach and tourist facilities adjacent to the harbour are remarkable. Service areas such as cafes, bars, as well as sun loungers can be rented nearby. Although there are no settlements around the harbour, the tourist atmosphere on the beach next to it stands out.

There is a small buffet near the pier. This sympathetic buffet is usually among the points frequented before boarding the ferry. In the meantime, with the arrangement of bus services close to the access hours of ships, an uninterrupted access is provided to the center of GÃ¶kÃ§eada. Taxi and car rental facilities are also available.
</html>

Der Hafen von Kuzu, ein Transferzentrum, ist auch eine Attraktion fÃ¼r seine Umgebung. Bemerkenswert sind der Strand und die touristischen Einrichtungen neben dem Hafen. Neben Servicebereichen wie CafÃ©s und Bars kÃ¶nnen in der NÃ¤he auch Sonnenliegen gemietet werden. Obwohl es rund um den Hafen keine Siedlung gibt, fÃ¤llt die touristische AtmosphÃ¤re am Strand daneben auf.

In der NÃ¤he des Hafens gibt es ein kleines Buffet. Dieses sympathische Buffet gehÃ¶rt zu den hÃ¤ufigen Zwischenstopps, bevor Sie auf die FÃ¤hre steigen. In der Zwischenzeit wird ein ununterbrochener Transport zum Zentrum von GÃ¶kÃ§eada angeboten, indem Busverbindungen in der NÃ¤he der Zugangszeiten der Schiffe organisiert werden. description.en:
It is located just north of the HÃ¼davendigar mosque in Bursa. The Tomb of I.Murad HÃ¼davendigar was built by YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m Beyazid.

As many people who loved and closely followed Ottoman history know, YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m Beyazid, is the son of I.Murat. The Tomb of I.Murad HÃ¼davendigar was also built in his name. As a result of the earthquake that took place in 1854, the shrine was completely destroyed. In fact, this earthquake negatively affects many structures in Bursa city at that time. It is rebuilt after the earthquake but it is quite far from its initial state. It is known that this period lasted exactly eight years. During the reign of II. Abdulhamid, it takes its present form.

The middle section of the dome, which is octagonal in shape, has brass railings. Within this area there's a crates belonging to I.Murad. Naturally, this is the most interesting sarcophagus here, but other than that, there are seven more crates in the tomb. Those who came to the tomb may also encounter crateses belonging to such names as Åehzade Yakup, son of I.Murad, his grandson Emir Suleyman and Åehzade Mehmet. Only the three crates could not be determined with certainty to whom they belonged.

I. Murad HÃ¼davendigar Mausoleum is known to have been built in 1389. When we examine the Tomb of Orhan Gazi, it is possible to see very serious similarities. Sultan I Murad, as it will be known to historians, was killed during the I.Kosovo War. I.Murad who lived between 1360 and 1389 is also referred by names such as HÃ¼davendigar or Ghazi HÃ¼nkar. At the entrance of the Tomb, two separate tombs meet you. One of them belongs to a magzuba who is known as Ã‡ekirge Sultan by the local people. He's also among the astrologers of I.Murad. The details of the decoration on the other tomb draw attention immediately. In the tomb,a woman who was buried here with the special permission of the Sultan lies.

The place where the tomb is located is one of the hill that dominates the city of Bursa. During the year, local visitors are attracted by the intense interest of I. Murad HÃ¼davendigar Mausoleum located in Osmangazi, Bursa.
description.de:
Das Grab vom I. Murad HÃ¼davendigar nÃ¶rdlich der HÃ¼davendigar-Moschee in Bursa wurde von YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m Beyazid erbaut.

Wie viele Menschen, die die osmanische Geschichte lieben und verfolgen, genau wissen, ist YÄ±ldÄ±rÄ±m Beyazid der Sohn vom I. Murad. Das Murad HÃ¼davendigar Mausoleum wurde fÃ¼r ihn gebaut. Das Grab wurde infolge des Erdbebens im Jahr 1854 vollstÃ¤ndig zerstÃ¶rt. TatsÃ¤chlich hat dieses Erdbeben zu dieser Zeit viele GebÃ¤ude in Bursa negativ beeinflusst. Es wird nach dem Erdbeben wieder aufgebaut, ist aber weit von seinem ursprÃ¼nglichen Zustand entfernt. Es ist bekannt, dass dieser Zeitraum genau acht Jahre dauerte. In der Regierungszeit vom II. Abdulhamit nimmt es seine derzeitige Form an.

Im mittleren Teil der Kuppel befinden sich MessinggelÃ¤nder, die eine achteckige Form haben. In diesem Gebiet befindet sich ein Sarkophag vom I. Murad. NatÃ¼rlich ist dies der Schrein, der die meiste Aufmerksamkeit auf sich zieht, aber es gibt sieben weitere Schreine im Grab. Diejenigen, die zum Mausoleum kommen, kÃ¶nnen auch auf Sarkophage von Namen wie Åehzade Yakup, Sohn vom I. Murad, seinem Enkel Emir SÃ¼leyman und Åehzade Mehmet stoÃŸen. Man konnte nicht herausfinden, wem die anderen 3 Schreine gehÃ¶ren.

Es ist bekannt, dass das Grab vom I. Murad HÃ¼davendigar 1389 erbaut wurde. Es ist mÃ¶glich, sehr ernsthafte Ã„hnlichkeiten zu erkennen, wenn wir das Grab von Orhan Gazi untersuchen. Sultan Murad I. wurde wÃ¤hrend des Kosovo-Krieges gemartert, wie es Historiker schon wissen. Murad, der zwischen 1360 und 1389 lebte, ist auch unter Namen wie HÃ¼davendigar oder Gazi HÃ¼nkar bekannt. Zwei GrÃ¤ber treffen Sie am Eingang des Grabes. Einer von ihnen gehÃ¶rt zu einer Gemeinde, die von den Einheimischen als Ã‡ekirge Sultan bekannt ist. Er gehÃ¶rt auch zu den Astrologen von Murad. Die Dekorationsdetails auf dem anderen Grab fallen sofort auf. Im Grab liegt eine Frau, die hier mit besonderer Erlaubnis des Sultans begraben wurde.

Der Ort, an dem sich das Mausoleum befindet, befindet sich auf einem der HÃ¼gel, die die Stadt Bursa dominieren. Das Grab vom I. Murad HÃ¼davendigar, das das ganze Jahr Ã¼ber die Aufmerksamkeit der Besucher auf sich zog, befindet sich in der Stadt Osmangazi in Bursa.

description.en:
It is the mosque addes to St. Ebul Hasan Harakani complex belatedly by Sultan Alparslan in the name of St. Ebul Hasan Harakani, one of the first martyr of the Turks scholar to enter Anatolia.

In Seljuk State, both soldiers and clerics are called Alperen who strive to take anatolian territory. Abul Hasan Harakani, who was born in The Horosan region of Iran in 963, is one of the most popular Alperens of the Seljuk State... The Seljuks who wanted to make Anatolia Turkish territory, when they wanted to start from Kars came here and fought against Byzantines, and became martyrs.

Sultan Alparslan, who took Kars exactly 40 years after Harakani was martyred in 1033, first built a complex where his grave was found. The complex, which consists of a lonely and simple size, is exhausted and worn out in hundreds of years. 

When the pages of history showed the year 1579, the Ottoman Sultan of the period Murad III. charged Grand vizier Lala Mustafa Pasha goes to architectural arrangements in Kars city. During this arrangement, Pasha restored the tomb, expands the location of the tomb and builds a mosque here. 

Ebul Hasan Harakani Mosque, which has been subjected to maintenance and repair work many times over time, was finally restored by the Harakani Foundation in 1996 and have its final status.
description.de:
Ebul Hasan Harakani, einer der ersten Gelehrten, der als MÃ¤rtyrer starb damit die TÃ¼rken Anatolien eintreten kÃ¶nnen, und sie ist eine Moschee, die spÃ¤ter von Sultan Alparslan dem Komplex hinzugefÃ¼gt wurde.

Diejenigen, die sowohl Soldaten als auch Geistliche im seldschukischen Staat waren und versuchten, ihr Land in Anatolien einzunehmen, werden Alperen genannt. Ebul Hasan Harakani, der 963 in der iranischen Horosan-Region auf die Welt kam, ist auch einer der beliebtesten Alperen des seldschukischen Staates.

Sultan Alparslan, der Kars 40 Jahre nach Harakanis MÃ¤rtyrertod im Jahr 1033 einnahm, baute zunÃ¤chst an der Stelle, an der sich sein Grab befand, einen Komplex. Der Komplex besteht aus einem einsamen und einfachen Mausoleum und ist Ã¼ber Hunderte von Jahren erschÃ¶pft und abgenutzt.

Als die GeschichtsbÃ¼cher 1579 zeigten, begab sich der GroÃŸwesir Erzieher Mustafa Pascha im Auftrag des damaligen osmanischen Sultans Murad der III. zu einer architektonischen Einrichtung in der Stadt Kars. WÃ¤hrend dieses Arrangements liess der Pascha das Grab restaurieren und erweiterte die Stelle, an der sich sein Grab befand. Hier baute er eine Moschee auf.

Die Ebul-Hasan-Harakani-Moschee, die im Laufe der Zeit viele Wartungs- und Reparaturarbeiten unterzogen wurde, wurde 1996 von der Harakani-Stiftung restauriert, indem sie ihrem Original treu blieb und ihre heutige Form annimmt.

description.en:
In fact, the Apple Church, a chapel, is one of the few structures that have survived from the 12th century without spoiling its frescoes almost intact.

The Pagan Emperor of Rome, Constantine I, becomes a Christian just hours before his death. The emperor, who has done countless evils all his life to the religion of Christianity and to those who believe in this religion, causes countless people to escape because of their faith. The Christian people who came to Nevsehir through Kayseri and Hatay and took refuge, where they find the opportunity to live their faith and live safely.

The people who breathed a sigh of relief as Constantine I became Christian just before he died do not leave Cappadocia and its surroundings and spread their religion all over Anatolia from here... NevÅŸehir, which has hosted many civilizations in its thousands of years of history dating back to the assyrian colonies and itâ€™s longest-term guests are The Christians for these reasons.

The Apple Church opens the doors of a mystical journey with scenes from the Bible and Torah on its walls. In one of the frescoes, the objects in the hands of the priests are likened to apples, so it takes this name. Thousands of local and foreign tourists flock here every year to see the frescoes, from the ascention to the Angel Mikail, from the Prophet of Souleiman to the Jewish kings includes many religious teachings.

description.en:
The HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Madrasa, located on KavaklÄ± Street in the region named Hisar in Bursa, was built towards the end of the 1500s and is one of the works that has a very important place in terms of history.


Bursa was the capital of the Ottoman Empire for a period, so it managed to have many cultural and historical monuments. The fact that these works have come to a large extent until today adds significant value to Bursa tourism. One of the important buildings inherited from the Ottoman period is the HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Madrasa. This place is reintroduced with the successful restoration work done in recent years and the restoration work has been carried out with the efforts of Osmangazi Municipality.


It is given such a name because of the tributes collected from Christians during the period when the place was built. Another name of HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Madrasa is 'Cizyederzade'. Although it is not known who exactly built the madrasa, a notable family of the city is mentioned in written sources. Essentially during the period of its establishment, this facility begins to serve as a kind of victory. Rifki Ibrahim Effendi decides to turn this place into a madrasa in later periods. The library to this madrasa manages to be the second largest library in the city. As it is known, the Orhan Library is in the first place. In fact, this library will merge with the Orhan Library after a while. The number of books here in the 1930s is around 1600. Today, a significant portion of those books are transferred to the Inebey Library of writing works.


The presence of the madrasa at a historical point of the city, such as KavaklÄ± quarter, is an important advantage in terms of tourism. The building section of the madrasa is about 110 square meters. The garden part is larger than this area. After the restoration, this historical Madrasa of Bursa is now transformed into a social facility that hosts cultural and artistic activities. HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Madrasa is also known as HÃ¼seyin AÄŸa Madrasa or HÃ¼seyin AÄŸa Zawiyah by the local people.
description.de:
HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Medresse befindet sich in der KavaklÄ±-StraÃŸe in Hisar in Bursa und ist eines der Werke, die Ende des 16. Jahrhunderts erbaut wurden und einen sehr wichtigen historischen Gesichtspunkt haben.

Bursa hat es geschafft, viele kulturelle und historische DenkmÃ¤ler zu haben, weil es fÃ¼r die osmanische Zeit eine Hauptstadt war. Die Tatsache, dass diese Arbeiten zu einem groÃŸen Teil bis heute erreichen konnten, trÃ¤gt wesentlich zum Tourismus in Bursa bei. Eine der wichtigsten Strukturen aus der osmanischen Zeit ist die HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Medresse. Dieser Ort kommt mit den erfolgreichen Restaurierungsarbeiten der letzten Jahre wieder auf die Tagesordnung, und die Restaurierungsarbeiten wurden mit den BemÃ¼hungen der Gemeinde Osmangazi durchgefÃ¼hrt.

Ein solcher Name wird wegen dem Schutzgeld gegeben, die von Christen wÃ¤hrend der Zeit, als der Ort gebaut wurde, gesammelt wurden. Ein anderer Name von HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Medresse ist "Cizyederzade". Obwohl nicht genau bekannt ist, wer die Medresse hergestellt hat, wird in den schriftlichen Quellen erwÃ¤hnt, dass eine fortgeschrittene Familie der Stadt erwÃ¤hnt wird. WÃ¤hrend der GrÃ¼ndungszeit begann diese Einrichtung als eine Art Sieg zu dienen. RÄ±fkÄ± Ä°brahim Efendi beschlieÃŸt, diesen Ort in den folgenden ZeitrÃ¤umen in eine Medresse zu verwandeln. Die in dieser Medresse erbaute Bibliothek ist die zweitgrÃ¶ÃŸte Bibliothek der Stadt. Die Orhan-Bibliothek nimmt bekanntlich den ersten Platz ein. Diese Bibliothek ist bereits nach einer Weile mit der Orhan-Bibliothek zusammengefÃ¼hrt. Die Anzahl der BÃ¼cher hier war in den 1930er Jahren um 1600. Heute wird ein wichtiger Teil dieser BÃ¼cher in die Inebey Manuskripten Bibliothek Ã¼bertragen.

Die Tatsache, dass sich die Medresse an einem historischen Punkt der Stadt wie dem KavaklÄ±-Bezirk befindet, ist ein wichtiger touristischer Vorteil. Der GebÃ¤udeteil der Medresse betrÃ¤gt ca. 110 Quadratmeter. Es ist bemerkenswert, dass der Gartenteil grÃ¶ÃŸer als dieser Bereich ist. Nach dieser Restaurierung verwandelt sich diese historische Medresse von Bursa in eine soziale Einrichtung, in der kulturelle und kÃ¼nstlerische AktivitÃ¤ten stattfinden. HaraÃ§Ã§Ä±oÄŸlu Medresse ist unter den Einheimischen auch als HÃ¼seyin AÄŸa Medresse oder HÃ¼seyin AÄŸa Derwischzelle bekannt.

description.en:
The Provincial General Assembly Building, one of the most beautiful structures of Kars, which has been transformed into a state building from an old church, is also one of the landmarks of the city.

On the streets of Kars, resembling Hollywood movie sets, a camera will always be appear from a corner and it gives you the impression that it will include you in the film. Of course, the main reason for this situation is that it is the shaping of the 19th century Russia of the city in Baltic architectural style. 

In the late 1800s, the Russians built numerous churches, theater halls, teachers' houses and headquarters buildings in Kars. These structures, usually one or two storeys, rarely come across as three floors. The Provincial General Assembly Building, which has reached this day as one of the most beautiful examples of Baltic architecture, is one of the Orthodox churches built at the time.

One of the great things about Kars is that wherever you turn your lens, it offers you the opportunity to capture a great photo. The building, which carries all the majesty of the city, fascinates those who see it, while it is among the structures that photo enthusiasts line up to frame.
description.de:
Das HauptparlamentgebÃ¤ude der Provinz, eines der schÃ¶nsten GebÃ¤ude von Kars, das aus einer alten Kirche in ein StaatsgebÃ¤ude umgewandelt wurde, ist auch eines der Wahrzeichen der Stadt.

In den StraÃŸen der Stadt Kars, die Hollywood-Kulissen Ã¤hnelt, kommt jederzeit eine Kamera aus einer Ecke und vermittelt den Eindruck, dass Sie in den Film einbezogen werden. NatÃ¼rlich ist der Hauptgrund fÃ¼r diese Situation, dass die Stadt vom russischen baltischen Baustil des 19. Jahrhunderts geprÃ¤gt ist.

In den spÃ¤ten 1800er Jahren bauten die Russen viele Kirchen, TheatersÃ¤le, Lehrerpensionen und Hauptquartiere in Kars. Diese Strukturen, die normalerweise ein- oder zweistÃ¶ckig sind, werden selten als dreistÃ¶ckig angesehen. Das GebÃ¤ude des Provinzialparlaments, eines der schÃ¶nsten Beispiele der baltischen Architektur, ist eine der orthodoxen Kirchen, die zu dieser Zeit erbaut wurden.

Einer der schÃ¶nsten Aspekte der Stadt Kars ist, dass Sie Ã¼berall, wohin Sie auch nur Ihre Kamera drehen, ein groÃŸartiges Foto aufnehmen kÃ¶nnen. WÃ¤hrend das GebÃ¤ude, das die ganze Pracht der Stadt trÃ¤gt, diejenigen bewundert, die es sehen, gehÃ¶rt es zu den Bauwerken, in denen Fotoenthusiasten ihre Fotos machen.

description.en:
<html>They are two most important rivers of Edirne. Even the region where the rivers are located is called the 'City of Waters'. Important promenade areas are located around both rivers. The MeriÃ§ River originates exactly within the borders of Bulgaria and enters Turkey over Edirne. It is also included in part of the borders of Greece.

The MeriÃ§ bridge over the MeriÃ§ River is sometimes referred to as the Mecidiye Bridge. The large promenade and rest areas along the bridge form a unity with the area. Due to the presence of both the river and promenade areas, Edirne is one of the places of interest to the people. The area of the river can be reached in a short time by minibuses departing from the city.

The MeriÃ§ River is also shown as one of the largest rivers in Rumeli. The river, which emerges from the northern part of Rhodope Mountain, first waters the Plovdiv Plain, then Edirne, and finally passes into Western Thrace. The total length of the MeriÃ§ River, which flows into the Aegean Sea, is around 490 kilometers. About half of this distance falls within the borders of Turkey. The Tunca is actually one of the tributaries of this great river. Besides Tunca, there are two other branches named Ergene and Arda. There is the Mustafa Kemal Pasha Bridge in one part of the river, which stands out for its elegant appearance. MeriÃ§ is also the name of a neighborhood in Edirne. This area is also the district most affected by the river.

The basin of the Meric River is located in Greece. One of the tributaries of the river spills into the Gulf of Saroz in Greece. This river also determines our border with Greece to a certain extent. MeriÃ§ is known as the 10th largest river in Turkey. In general, it has a vicious characteristic. For this reason, it may damage some residential areas due to its flow rate. The amount of water it carries during winter periods increases considerably.
</html>

Es sind die beiden wichtigsten FlÃ¼sse der Stadt Edirne. TatsÃ¤chlich wird das Gebiet, in dem sich die FlÃ¼sse befinden, als "Stadt der GewÃ¤sser" bezeichnet. Die MeriÃ§-BrÃ¼cke Ã¼ber dem Fluss MeriÃ§ wird manchmal als Mecidiye-BrÃ¼cke bezeichnet. Der Fluss MeriÃ§ gilt auch als einer der grÃ¶ÃŸten FlÃ¼sse Rumeliens. Der Fluss entspringt aus dem nÃ¶rdlichen Teil des Rhodopengebirges und Ã¼berflutet zuerst die Plovdiv-Ebene, dann Edirne und flieÃŸt schlieÃŸlich nach Westthrakien. Die GesamtlÃ¤nge des Flusses MeriÃ§, der in die  Ã„gÃ¤is mÃ¼ndet, betrÃ¤gt rund 490 Kilometer. UngefÃ¤hr die HÃ¤lfte dieser Entfernung flieÃŸt in die Grenzen der TÃ¼rkei. Tunca ist tatsÃ¤chlich einer der Zweige dieses groÃŸen Flusses. Neben Tunca gibt es zwei weitere Niederlassungen mit den Namen Ergene und Arda. In einem Teil des Flusses befindet sich die Mustafa Kemal Pascha BrÃ¼cke, die sich durch ihr elegantes Erscheinungsbild auszeichnet. MeriÃ§ ist auch ein Bezirksname in Edirne. Diese Region ist der am stÃ¤rksten vom Fluss betroffene Bezirk.

Das Einzugsgebiet des Flusses MeriÃ§ befindet sich in Griechenland. Einer der Flussarme flieÃŸt in die Bucht von Saros in Griechenland. Dieser Fluss bestimmt bis zu einem gewissen Grad auch unsere Grenze zu Griechenland. Meric, bekannt als der zehntgrÃ¶ÃŸte Fluss der TÃ¼rkei. Im Allgemeinen hat es eine kÃ¤mpferische Eigenschaft. Aus diesem Grund kann es aufgrund seiner Durchflussrate einige Wohngebiete beschÃ¤digen. Die Menge an Wasser, die es trÃ¤gt, nimmt im Winter erheblich zu.

description.en:
<html>We are at the eternal resting point of the rulers of the Anatolian Seljuk State. In the early 12th century. The tomb built by KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan II is still home to the Turkish rulers of the past period.

The work, which belongs to the classical Seljuk architectural period, is included in the construction of the Aladdin Mosque. The tomb, which houses the tomb of many of the sultans of the Seljuk State of Anatolia, reigned between 1156 and 1192. It is built by KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan II, who also carried out the first coin printing of his state. Kilic Arslan is a politician and statesman who has contributed greatly to the progress of the Seljuks during his time on the throne.

When you look at its architectural features, the dome of the tomb, which is shaped like a prism with 10 faÃ§ade from cut stones, is also in the form of a cone with 10 corners. The work, made by son of the Abdulgaffar, Yusuf, an architect, stands firm, despite more than 800 years elapsed. 

When the inside of the tomb is examined, niche and tile use of important features of Seljuk architecture stand out. Vertical niches extend to the dome, affecting its explorers in their glory. Inside the tomb there are also sandukas made with the art of tile decoration. Over time, the tiles on the sandukas that destroyed were repaired in 2006.

The work of historians and archaeologists is clear that eight sultan's tombs are located in the Tomb of seljuk sultans. In the tomb there is a sanduka for each sultan's tomb, Mesud I, Alaaddin Keykubat I, GÄ±yaseddin KeyhÃ¼srev I, KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan II, RÃ¼kneddin Suleiman II, GÄ±yaseddin KeyhÃ¼srev II, GÄ±yaseddin KeyhÃ¼srev III and IV. The tombs of The KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan are located.
</html>
description.de:
<html>Wir befinden uns am ewigen Ruhepunkt der Herrscher des anatolischen seldschukischen Staates. Das Grab, das KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan dem II. zu Beginn des 12. Jahrhunderts errichtete, beherbergt noch immer frÃ¼here tÃ¼rkische Herrscher.

Das Werk, das zur klassischen seldschukischen Architekturzeit gehÃ¶rt, ist im Bau der Alaaddin-Moschee enthalten. Das Grab, in dem sich die GrÃ¤ber vieler Sultane des anatolischen Seldschukenreichs befinden, wurde zwischen 1156 und 1192 von KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan dem II., der in der Zeit regierte, gebaut. Er fÃ¼hrte auch den ersten MÃ¼nzdruck seines Staates durch. KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan ist ein Politiker und Staatsmann, der wÃ¤hrend seines Aufenthaltes auf dem Thron einen groÃŸen Beitrag zum Fortschritt der Seldschuken geleistet hat.

In Anbetracht seiner architektonischen Merkmale hat die Kuppel des Grabes, die die Form eines Prismas mit 10 FlÃ¤chen hat, auch die Form eines Kegels mit 10 Ecken. Die Arbeit von Yusuf, dem Sohn von Abdulgaffar, bleibt trotz mehr als 800 Jahren intakt.

Wenn das Innere des Grabes untersucht wird, ist die Verwendung von Nischen und Fliesen eines der wichtigen Merkmale der seldschukischen Architektur. Vertikale Nischen erstrecken sich bis zur Kuppel und beeindrucken ihre Entdecker mit ihrem Ruhm. Im Inneren des Grabes befinden sich auch Sarkophage, die mit der Kunst der Fliesendekoration hergestellt wurden. Die im Laufe der Zeit zerstÃ¶rten Fliesen an den Sarkophagen wurden 2006 repariert.

Aus der Arbeit von Historikern und ArchÃ¤ologen geht hervor, dass sich im Mausoleum der seldschukischen Sultane acht SultangrÃ¤ber befinden. FÃ¼r jedes Sultangrab gibt es einen Sarkophag, hier befinden sich die GrÃ¤ber von Mesud dem I., Alaaddin Keykubat dem I., GÄ±yaseddin KeyhÃ¼srev dem I., KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan dem II.,  RÃ¼kneddin SÃ¼leyman dem II., GÄ±yaseddin KeyhÃ¼srev dem II., GÄ±yaseddin KeyhÃ¼srev dem III. und KÄ±lÄ±Ã§ Arslan dem IV.
</html>

description.en:
<html>Harran is among the few architectural sites of the world with its texture and atmosphere. The mold houses here are named as it because of its form of a dome.

These domed houses, which have been used for over 150-200 years, have no similar with it in the world! It has a cool summer and a structure that maintains the heat inside the winters due to the materials used in the construction of Harran KÃ¼mbet Houses, which is also very cute with its side-by-side cylindrical architecture. According to the rumors, the reason for the protection of the temperature of the houses is said to be adding rose oil into the specially prepared soil.

Harran's conical domed houses were created with stones collected from the ruins near the ancient city. Built on average 200 years ago, these houses are built on a prismatic foundation for squares. These houses, which are 5 meters high, are built with a series of 30-40 bricks. Only one door is left open and decorated according to the culture of Harran region.

You also have the chance to walk into Harran KÃ¼mbet Houses, which are considered as site areas today donâ€™t forget to get picture in this are. 

</html>
description.de:
<html>Es ist einer der seltenen Orte, an denen sich die besten Architekturen der Welt mit seiner Harran-Textur und AtmosphÃ¤re befinden. Hier haben die KuppelhÃ¤user diesen Namen angenommen, weil das Dach die Form einer Kuppel hat.

Diese KuppelhÃ¤user, die seit mehr als 150-200 Jahren genutzt werden, haben keine andere auf der Welt! Harran KuppelhÃ¤user, das mit seiner nebeneinander angeordneten zylindrischen Architektur ein sehr hÃ¼bsches Aussehen hat, hat eine Struktur, die im Sommer kÃ¼hl ist und die Hitze im Winter schÃ¼tzt. GerÃ¼chten zufolge soll dem speziell vorbereiteten Boden RosenÃ¶l zugesetzt worden sein, um die Temperatur der HÃ¤user aufrechtzuerhalten.

Die konischen KuppelhÃ¤user von Harran wurden mit Steinen geformt, die aus den Ruinen in der NÃ¤he der antiken Stadt gesammelt wurden. Diese HÃ¤user, die vor 200 Jahren gebaut wurden, sind prismatisch auf quadratischen Boden oder Quadrat gebaut. Diese HÃ¤user, von denen das hÃ¶chste 5 Meter hoch ist, sind aus 30-40 Ziegeln gebaut.

Sie haben auch die MÃ¶glichkeit, Harran KuppelhÃ¤user zu besuchen, das heute als SIT-Gebiet gilt. Vergessen Sie nicht, Fotos in diesem Bereich zu machen, in dem nur eine TÃ¼r offen bleibt und die Region Harran entsprechend der Kultur eingerichtet ist.

</html>

description.en:
<html>The history of ikonion, which is the origin of the name today, dates back thousands of years. Nearly the last thousand years of the city have been under Seljuk and Ottoman rule, bringing the cultural and artistic heritage of the time to the present day. Located in the center of the city, Konya Ethnography Museum is an intriguing building where this heritage can be seen closely with its various elements. 

The museum, which began service in 1975, features a conference hall, carpet section and warehouse from the ground to the first floor. Various collections of works and traditional crafts can be examined in exhibition halls. In this context, ethnographic examples of extraordinary width from shalwar to bindallÄ±, from caftan women's ornaments stand out. After the date journey between bedding, satin fabrics, clothes prepared with various traditional techniques and many other works, such as pots, bowl, ewer, mortar, censer, mill, tobacco pouches items related to daily life can be seen. Examples of this rich collection continue with manuscript, hundreds of years of manuscripts Qurans, mirrors, writing drawers and various cultural items. 

The adventure of Konya Ethnography Museum is completed with war materials such as swords and shields and a large collection of carpets... The unique carpets exhibited in the museum, as well as Konya, call it a visual feast with rich examples of Anatolian geography.
</html>
description.de:
<html>Die Geschichte der Stadt Ikonion, die heute den Namenursprung erschaffen hat, reicht Jahrtausende zurÃ¼ck. Die letzten tausend Jahre der Stadt standen unter der Herrschaft der Seldschuken und Osmanen und trugen das kulturelle und kÃ¼nstlerische Erbe der Zeit. Das Konya Ethnographische Museum im Zentrum der Stadt ist ein interessantes Bauwerk, in dem dieses Erbe mit verschiedenen Elementen genau betrachtet werden kann.

Das Museum, das 1975 seinen Dienst aufnahm, verfÃ¼gt Ã¼ber Bereiche wie Konferenzsaal, Teppichabteilung und Lager vom Boden bis zum ersten Stock. In den Ausstellungshallen kÃ¶nnen verschiedene Kunst- und Handwerkskollektionen besichtigt werden. In diesem Zusammenhang fallen auÃŸerordentlich breite ethnografische Beispiele von Salwar bis Bindal, von Kaftan bis zu Frauenornamenten auf. Nach der historischen Reise zwischen Bettbezug, Satinstoffen, Kleidung, die mit verschiedenen traditionellen Techniken hergestellt wurde, und vielen anderen Arbeiten sind KÃ¼chenutensilien wie TÃ¶pfe, Schalen, Krug, StÃ¶ÃŸel, Weihrauchbrenner, MÃ¼hle und GegenstÃ¤nde des tÃ¤glichen Lebens wie Tesbih und Tabakbeutel zu sehen. Diese reichhaltige Sammlung von Manuskripten setzt sich mit jahrhundertelangem Koranmanuskript, Spiegeln, Schreibschubladen und verschiedenen kulturellen GegenstÃ¤nden fort.

Das Abenteuer des Konya Ethnographischen Museums wird mit Kriegsmaterialien wie Schwertern und Schilden und einer mÃ¶glichst groÃŸen Teppichsammlung beendetâ€¦ Die im Museum ausgestellten einzigartigen Teppiche versprechen ein visuelles Fest mit reichhaltigen Beispielen der anatolischen Geographie sowie Konya.
</html>

description.en:
Izmir is known as the third largest city in Turkey. Rebuplic Square is located in the center of Izmir, a major metropolis, and is considered as one of the two major squares of the city. It is located right in the middle of Alsancak and Ã‡ankaya districts in the Konak district of Izmir. Metro, bus or tram pass very close to the square. Republic Square is one of the city's truly symbolic places. A monument representing AtatÃ¼rk's order â€œthe armies are your first target, the Mediterranean, forwardâ€ is located here. The fact that the square is located on the beach makes this place much more popular.

As is known, Izmir faced a great fire disaster in 1922. This fire would cause the destruction or demoslished  of many buildings in the city. After the fire and the war, Izmir is almost rebuilt. Republic Square can also be considered as one of the important projects in this process. An Italian sculptor makes the famous AtatÃ¼rk monument in Cumhuriyet Square. In spite of this, BehÃ§et Uz also makes serious contributions to the completion of the monument. BehÃ§et Uz was the mayor of Izmir at the same time. It is known that 40 thousand TL was spent in those years for the monument situated in the square. The inauguration of the AtatÃ¼rk monument takes place in 1932.

This historical square behind the grand Ephesus Hotel is the scene of many activities and events in Izmir. Parties organize their big rallies here from time to time. On special occasions, municipalities use this square as an event space. Republic Square, where people gather and mingle with social activities in a sense, is also seen as a stop-and-rest area for those who walk in the cordon, watching the sun set or the sea. Republic Square is also very close to GÃ¼ndoÄŸdu Square and Konak Square.

description.en:
The Aga mosque is one of the most prominent Ottoman Empire-era monuments in Gaziantep, one of the most important cities in southeastern Turkey. The mosque, located on the Unnamed Martyrs Street in the district of Åahinbey, has been standing for centuries as an element that defines the historical identity of the street.

Agha Mosque, while Antep was not yet given â€™gazi' title, was built by Ferruh Agha, who served as the prefect here hundreds of years ago. The construction of the mosque, which was started in 1554, ends in 1559, and it is clear as day that it was created with five years of feverish work. According to the inscription, the mosque is in its original state exactly 250 years after it was built and goes through a comprehensive restoration process.

The mosque, which has a rectangular plan, consists of a plan with two longitudinal nave. These sections, which have six sections and are covered by cross vaults with gable, are described as quite remarkable. While the dome in front of the mihrab impresses its visitors with its beauty, the fact that it is plain and far from ostentatious in general blends it with the splendor of simplicity.

There is a fountain right next to the entrance door in the small courtyard of the Agha Mosque, which has a single minaret balcony and a very short minaret. The mosque with its inviting atmosphere and the wisdom of the centuries that gives the impression of a hospitable Anatolian person is one of the most important and oldest architectural structures in Gaziantep,.

description.en:
The first places that come to mind when it is called summer tourism in Turkey are Antalya and MuÄŸla. Especially the beaches in Marmaris district of MuÄŸla manage to have a worldwide reputation. One of these beaches, UzunyalÄ± Beach, is one of the most ideal places to enter the sea in the region. The fact that this beach is adjacent to Marmaris public beach is very effective in making it known and popular. You can easily reach the beach thanks to the minibuses moving from the centre of Marmaris. UzunyalÄ± Beach has a coast of approximately 10 kilometers. There are many restaurants and cafes along the coast. Despite the crowds, the beach attracts attention with its clean sea and sandy beach.


The popularity of this private beach, which manages to add significant value to tourism in Marmaris, increases a little more every summer. If you want to come to UzunyalÄ± Beach, which is 10 kilometers from Marmaris district center, you can take advantage of the signs along the way. After coming to the district center, you can switch from Kemal Seyfettin Elgin Boulevard to the beach. Entry to the beach is free at the moment. On the other hand, you can take advantage of services such as sun loungers and showers at a reasonable price. UzunyalÄ± Beach, which is shown among the elite beaches, hosts numerous events throughout the summer. Especially sports activities increase the colorfulness of the beach. UzunyalÄ± Beach is often inspected and is generally seen as a reliable beach.


There are no specific restrictions on visiting the beach. Therefore, you can come to UzunyalÄ± Beach at any time, but you can not use the services for the beach after a certain hour. The beach is often preferred by families with children. Besides enjoying the beach, it is also convenient to picnic at UzunyalÄ± Beach which is preferred by families.

description.en:
The definition of pearl of the east for Kars is very accurate... The city, which has a unique cultural mosaic meaning for a large segment, has maintained its importance throughout history. The fact that the city is located on important trade routes in the Middle Ages has made the dynamic of military power in the region a priority for centuries. 

Built in this direction more than a thousand years ago, The Castle of Micingirt Vault is located on a steep cliff and the first date of construction extends to Roman domination according to estimates. Over time, Kars, which is under Byzantine domination, seljuk and then saltuklu principality management is experienced. Governor is mentioned in the records that Sultan Mansur Ergin strengthened and repaired the castle. 

As part of its active use, The Micingirt Vault Castle changes hands once again with Kars and its surroundings, which finally join the borders of the Ottoman Empire. Evliya Ã‡elebi, one of the 17th-century travellers, speaks of Micingirt Vault Castle in his work Travel Book. It states that there are about 200 households within the castle and 150 soldiers have been deployed. 

The historical castle, which has been reached as destroyed columns to the present day, takes the same name as the vault built during the Saltuklu period, and the following centuries continue to be called Micingirt Vault Castle.
description.de:
Die Definition der Schatz des Ostens ist fÃ¼r Kars sehr zutreffend. Die Stadt, die ein einzigartiges kulturelles Mosaik fÃ¼r ein breites Segment aufweist, ist im Laufe der Geschichte von Bedeutung geblieben. Die Tatsache, dass die Stadt im Mittelalter an wichtigen Handelswegen lag, machte die Dynamik der MilitÃ¤rmacht, die in der Region eingesetzt werden sollte, Ã¼ber Jahrhunderte zu einem vorrangigen Thema.

Dementsprechend befindet sich die vor mehr als tausend Jahren erbaute Micingirt-Kuppel-Burg auf einem steilen Felsen, und das erste Datum ihres Baus geht nach SchÃ¤tzungen auf die rÃ¶mische Herrschaft zurÃ¼ck. In Kars, das im Laufe der Zeit unter byzantinische Herrschaft geriet, wird die Verwaltung von Seldschuk und dann von Saltuklu Beylik erlebt. Der Saltuklu Herr Sultan Mansur Ergin ist in den Aufzeichnungen verzeichnet, dass er die Burg verstÃ¤rkt und repariert hat.

Im Rahmen seiner aktiven Nutzung wechselt Micingirt Kuppelburg erneut den Besitzer von Kars und seiner Umgebung, die sich den Grenzen des Osmanischen Reiches anschlieÃŸt. Evliya Ã‡elebi, einer der Reisenden aus dem 17. Jahrhundert, erwÃ¤hnt Micingirt Kuppelburg in seinem Werk mit dem Titel SeyahatnÃ¢me. Es gibt an, dass sich in der Burg ungefÃ¤hr 200 RÃ¤ume befinden und 150 Soldaten eingesetzt wurden.

Die historische Festung, deren Mauern bis heute zerstÃ¶rt wurden, trÃ¤gt denselben Namen wie die wÃ¤hrend der Saltuklu-Zeit errichtete Kuppel und wird auch in den folgenden Jahrhunderten als Micingirt-Kuppel-Burg bezeichnet.

description.en:
One of the prominent tourist districts of MuÄŸla, touching the sea with a wide coastline, is the location of IÃ§meler Beach, famous for its golden sand, in Marmaris. The beach, which gives its name to the town where it is located, draws attention to its location close to the town center. This beautiful beach, where it is possible to arrive in 8-10 minutes from the centre, is one of the most popular places for summer holidays for many local and foreign tourists coming to the city.


Although not very wide, the beach in front of the palm trees and the magnificent sea stretches along offer visitors,sunbathers, people sipping drinks under wicker umbrellas, 7 to 70 people of all ages in the sea to enter the lively atmosphere.In the meantime, it should be noted that the sea of this beach is not too stagnant.


Water sports are intense in the beach, canoeing and colorful activities such as bananas can be found. There is also the possibility of sea parachuting for those who want to experience adrenaline even higher. The charming town of IÃ§meler is also among the ideal locations for a quiet holiday.

description.en:
<html>Birecik Castle, built in time for assyrians and undergoing repairs in various periods, is famous for its walls built from cutting stones and with a height of up to 40 meters. These walls are so famous that everyone who visits the castle especially wants to listen to the legend that has reached the present day by word of mouth...

Although the exact production date is unclear, the Romans (after 395 DC, before 30 BC 13th century), franks (1098-1150 DC) and Memlukler (1277-1484) were repaired. There are two remaining doors from the walls surrounding birecik district. Don't forget to take photo at Urfa door and MeÃ§an door. Let's also say that there is only one left of the basiton, which is known to be 12 in the first construction of the castle.

If we need to briefly tell the story about the known legend about Birecik Castle, we'll have a death row inmate. In real the innocent prisoner is asked his last wish before the execution... The prisoner speaks about his filly. The prisoner, who says they're very loyal to each other, he wants to see his filly for the last time. And he says that the filly misses him, and even when they see the filly, they'll see him fill a hole with tears. When the gendarme goes to see the filly and sees it open a hole next to the filly and fill it with tears. When that happens, they take the filly with them and return to the castle and show it to the prisoner. 

Of course, when it sees the owner, it rears up, and the owner is attached to the shackles and chains. Unable to calm the filly, the prisoner says, "Untie me, to touch my filly for the last time so it calms down." The authorities will talk to each other and let the man. As soon as the prisoner's shackles are dissolved, he rides on his filly and it flies at full speed into the Euphrates River. Now you can't see the Euphrates River at the point where, of course, but at that time the water of the Euphrates, was licked the walls of the castle... Since than nobody met neither the prisoner nor the filly. The couple disappeared in the Euphrates waters...

</html>
description.de:
<html>Die Birecik-Burg, die wÃ¤hrend der Assyrer erbaut wurde und zu verschiedenen Zeiten repariert wurde, ist berÃ¼hmt fÃ¼r ihre Mauern aus geschnittenen Steinen mit einer HÃ¶he von 40 Metern. Diese Mauern sind so berÃ¼hmt, dass jeder, der das Schloss besucht, besonders die Legende hÃ¶ren mÃ¶chte, die weitererzÃ¤hlt werdenâ€¦

Obwohl das genaue Datum des Baus nicht bekannt ist, haben die RÃ¶mer (305 v. Chr. Und 395 v. Chr.), die Franken (1098-1150 v. Chr.) und die Mamluken (1277-1484) die Burg Birecik repariert, von der bekannt ist, dass sie ab dem 13. Jahrhundert erhalten ist. Es gibt zwei verbleibende TÃ¼ren von den Mauern, die das Birecik-Viertel umgeben. Vergessen Sie nicht, Fotos an der Urfa-TÃ¼r und der MeÃ§an-TÃ¼r zu machen. Nehmen wir auch an, dass es im Turm nur noch einen gibt, von dem bekannt ist, dass er im ersten Bau der Burg 12 Basteien hatte.

Wenn wir kurz Ã¼ber die bekannte Legende Ã¼ber die Burg Birecik sprechen mÃ¼ssen, werden wir auf einen Gefangenen in der Todeszelle stoÃŸen. Dieser Gefangene, der ursprÃ¼nglich nicht schuldig war, wurde vor der Hinrichtung nach seinem letzten Wunsch gefragt. Der Gefangene erklÃ¤rt, dass sie einander sehr treu sind und sagt, dass er das Fohlen noch einmal sehen mÃ¶chte. Und das Fohlen wÃ¼rde ihn vermissen, und selbst wenn sie das Fohlen sehen, werden sie sehen, dass sie ein Loch mit TrÃ¤nen fÃ¼llen. Die Beamten gehen, um das Fohlen zu sehen, als dies der Fall war, sahen sie tatsÃ¤chlich ein Loch neben dem Fohlen und es fÃ¼llt das Loch mit TrÃ¤nen. Danach nahmen sie das Fohlen mit, kehrten zur Burg zurÃ¼ck und zeigten es dem Gefangenen. NatÃ¼rlich sollte man das Fohlen sehen, als er den Besitzer sah, dass er an Fesseln und Ketten gebunden war. Er verurteilte die Beamten, die das Fohlen nicht beruhigen konnten: "LÃ¶se mich, lass mich mein Fohlen ein letztes Mal berÃ¼hren, damit er sich beruhigt." Die Beamten sprechen miteinander und erlauben es dem Mann. Sobald sich die Fesseln der Gefangenen aufgelÃ¶st haben, steigt er auf sein Fohlen und galoppiert zum FÄ±rat Fluss. NatÃ¼rlich kann man den FÄ±rat Fluss heutzutage nicht an der damaligen Stelle sehen, aber damals war das Wasser bis zu den Mauern der Burg. Die beiden verschwanden im Wasser des FÄ±rat Flussesâ€¦
</html>

description.en:
Ankara, the capital of the Republic of Turkey, has a leading position in the context of being a cultural synthesis. It is the focus of numerous works that have survived to the present day with its lands that were home to ancient civilizations such as Hittite, Rome. It also has museums of the modern past. Among these museums, Ankara PTT Museum is located in a separate location.

Ankara PTT Museum is a modern cultural building with a systematic display of thousands of stamps along with various nostalgic items. The museum, which attracts the attention of young and old people with its stamps of almost all nationalities exhibited in its building with its construction history dating back to the 1920s and bearing traces of Neo-classical architecture, has a special place in the hearts of especially collectors.

The PTT Stamp Museum, which was restored and inaugurated in 2013 and is also noted for its modern texture, can be visited every day of the week, except for official and religious holidays, between 09:00 and 17:00 free of charge.

description.en:
It is unclear exactly when and by whom the Kyrgyz Mausoleum in Bursa was built. Despite this, the knowledge that the building was built prior to the acquisition of Iznik is accepted with certainty.


Children's and adult sarcophagi are found in the Kyrgyz Mausoleum. It is currently known that there are eight sarcophagi in total within the shrine. The space, which has a north and south direction, is co-dimensional. Therefore, it is square in plan. Consisting of two independent areas, the Kyrgyz Mausoleum connects a large gate located in the middle section of the walls. This door is rectangular and does not have any inscriptions on it. The part in the southern part is covered with a dome. The pencil-work decorations on the sides of the upper windows are admirable. It is understood that the iwan section has been overhauled from time to time. The original parts of this area survive to the present day. The presence of rough-hewn stones adds value to the place.


Orhan Ghazi's signature is seen in the construction of the mausoleum, which is one of the most important sacred places in Bursa and which is particularly attracted to local visitors. In the records, the date of establishment is 1331, even though it is not certain. It is built in memory of the Kyrgyz Turks who fought for the Ottoman favor during the conquest of Iznik and lost their lives. The place is evaluated within the scope of Ottoman works of the first period. The mausoleum and Orhan Ghazi Zawiyah are immediately facing each other. Unfortunately, only the foundations of these lodges are found today. Local people sometimes refer to this place as â€˜KÄ±rkkÄ±zlar Mausoleumâ€™. In fact, it is possible to find the name â€˜Haji Camaza Mausoleumâ€™ in some sources.


The main space of the building, which has been attributed a special importance due to its architectural details and especially its pen-work decorations, is just behind the vaulted iwan. Together with the vault, the roof cannot reach today. A wooden flat roof is installed in place of the original roof.

Im kirgisischen Mausoleum gibt es Sarkophage fÃ¼r Kinder und Erwachsene. Derzeit ist bekannt, dass sich im Grab acht Sarkophage befinden. Der Raum in Nord- und SÃ¼drichtung ist gleich groÃŸ. Daher hat es eine quadratische Form als Plan. Es besteht aus einer groÃŸen TÃ¼r in der Mitte der Mauern des kirgisischen Mausoleums, die aus zwei unabhÃ¤ngigen Bereichen besteht. Diese TÃ¼r hat eine rechteckige Form und ist nicht beschriftet. Der Abschnitt im SÃ¼dabschnitt ist mit einer Kuppel bedeckt. Bewundernswert sind die handgezeichneten Verzierungen an den RÃ¤ndern der oberen Fenster. Es versteht sich, dass der iwan-Abschnitt von Zeit zu Zeit Ã¼berarbeitet wurde. Die ursprÃ¼nglichen Teile dieses Gebiets reichen bis heute. Das Vorhandensein von grob geschnittenen Steinen erhÃ¶ht den Wert des Raums.

Orhan Gazis Unterzeichnung ist im Bau des Mausoleums zu sehen, das einer der wichtigsten heiligen Orte von Bursa ist und vor allem lokale Besucher interessiert. Das GrÃ¼ndungsdatum ist 1331, auch wenn es in den Aufzeichnungen nicht sicher ist. Es wurde in Erinnerung an die kirgisischen TÃ¼rken erbaut, die fÃ¼r die Osmanen kÃ¤mpften und wÃ¤hrend der Eroberung von Iznik ihr Leben verloren. Der Ort wird im Rahmen der ersten Periode osmanischer Werke bewertet. Das Mausoleum und die Orhan Gazi Zawiya stehen sofort gegenÃ¼ber. Leider hat diese Zawiya heute nur die Grundlagen. Die Einheimischen bezeichnen dies von Zeit zu Zeit als â€KÄ±rkkÄ±zlar-Grabâ€œ. TatsÃ¤chlich ist es in einigen Quellen mÃ¶glich, auf den Namen 'Haci Camaza Mausoleum' zu stoÃŸen.

Der Hauptort des GebÃ¤udes, dem aufgrund seiner architektonischen Details und insbesondere seiner handgeschnitzten Verzierungen besondere Bedeutung beigemessen wurde, befindet sich direkt hinter dem gewÃ¶lbten Iwan. Zusammen mit dem GewÃ¶lbeteil kann das Dach bis heute nicht mehr erreichen. Anstelle des ursprÃ¼nglichen Daches wird ein hÃ¶lzernes Flachdach installiert.

description.en:
Buca Pond is known as one of the most important leisure and entertainment places in Izmir. Located outside the center of Buca Township, The pond is of intense interest, especially during the summer months. The construction of the area covering a total area of 167 thousand square meters was started in 1998. A year from 1998, it will be opened. Buca Pond has a separate restaurant with a total capacity of 300 people. There are also special areas such as children's play parks, market, delicatessen, babysitting room, picnic area, amphitheater. There are many venues around it that host country weddings.

Many concerts organized by the municipality are organized during the summer months in Buca pond. At the same time, summer cinema events have been held in the pond for several years. Local people who want to escape the scorching heat or the noise of the city often visit Buca pond. One of the most interesting parts of Buca Pond is the amphitheater. This section has a total capacity of 3,500 people. There are animations and various organizations throughout the summer that allow visitors to have a nice time. The wedding hall located inside the pond has a capacity of 700 people. Lake Hall is often preferred for company meals or wedding, circumcision meals.

At Buca Lake market, products brought from Buca villages are presented at stalls on certain days of the week. For the barbecue, it is only necessary to head to the designated private areas. It is possible to use buses and vans to go to Buca pond. Especially the dolmush will continue to serve until late and will take you to Buca town centre. Access to Buca Pond is always free. There is a large parking area here for those who want to come by private car.

description.en:
<html>The second-longest city after Istanbul, Antakya has Castle,the longest wall which is the symbol of Hatay and is one of the most important structures in the world, dates back to 300 BC.

Located in the middle of mesopotamia, known as "Milk and honey flowing land", which is the first known life in the world and means "the country between the two rivers", Hatay has thousands of years of history. The castle and walls of the city,the castle and the walls which has hosted numerous cultures and civilizations, are among the most valuable works not only in Turkey but also in the world.

The fortifications and walls of Antioch were built by General Seleucos I. Nikator, one of the most important men of King Alexander the Great of Macedonia, in 300 a.m. Justianus, the Byzantine Emperor of Byzantine, added to the castle used by many civilizations in the pages of history in the 6th century.

Antakya Castle and its walls, which have managed to come to this day with its rich culture stretching from Anatolian Seljuks to Romans, Ottoman to Byzantine, have five gates. These are the Iron Gate to the east, the Aleppo Gate to the north, the Bridge Gate to the west, the Damascus Gate to the south and the Dog Gate in the northwest.
</html>
description.de:
<html>Die Geschichte der Burg von Antakya und ihrer Mauern, die das Wahrzeichen von Hatay ist, der zweiten Stadt mit dem lÃ¤ngsten Wasser nach Istanbul und einem der wichtigsten Bauwerke der Welt, reicht bis 300 v. Chr. zurÃ¼ck.

Hatay liegt in der Mitte von Mesopotamien, was das erste bekannte Leben in der Welt und â€œdas Land zwischen den beiden FlÃ¼ssenâ€ bedeutet. Die Kenan Region, bekannt als "Milch und Honig flieÃŸendes Land", hat eine Geschichte von Tausenden von Jahren. Das Schloss ist als die Heimat von zahlreichen Kulturen und Zivilisationen und Mauern dient nicht nur in der TÃ¼rkei, sondern gehÃ¶rt auch zu den wertvollsten Werken der Welt.

Die Burg von Antakya und ihre Mauern wurden 300 v. Chr. von General Seleucos I. Nikator errichtet, einem der bedeutendsten MÃ¤nner des mazedonischen KÃ¶nigs Alexander der GroÃŸe. Der byzantinische Kaiser Justianus fÃ¼gte das Schloss, das von vielen Zivilisationen auf den Seiten der Geschichte im 6. Jahrhundert benutzt wurde, hinzu.

Anatolische Seldschuken, RÃ¶mer, Osmanen und Byzantiner. Die Burg von Antakya, die mit ihrer reichen Kultur bis heute Ã¼berlebt hat, hat fÃ¼nf Tore. Dies sind das Eisentor im Osten, das Aleppo-Tor im Norden (St. Paul-Tor), das BrÃ¼ckentor im Westen, das Damaskustor im SÃ¼den und das Hundetor im Nordwesten.</html>

description.en:
This house, where The Founder of the State of the Republic of Turkey, Headteacher Gazi Mustafa Kemal Ataturk stayed, was on his way back to Ankara after the Sivas Congress, has an important place in Turkish history.

Ataturk, who started the War of Independence in order to save the occupied territories of the Ottoman Empire and give the people a fully independent form of governance, takes many preliminary steps to lay the foundations of this war. The Sivas Congress, the last pre-war meeting organized by bringing together the country's leading soldiers, artists and scientists, is also the most important of these steps.

Ataturk, who set out to return to Ankara after the Sivas Congress, the last meeting organized to restore the Turkish nation's full independent form of governance,while returnÅŸng he changes his route maining pass through Nevsehir in order to visit Hajibektas-i Veli Hazret and stays at this house, which is also has great importance interms of architecture, between 22-23 December 1923

His house, the most magnificent of those created from adobe and hatÄ±l materials of the 19th century, this house is one of the most simple and stylish examples of Ottoman civil architecture style. The building was restored in 2001 by the Ministry of Culture and Tourism in accordance with its originality and is one of the most visited works of NevÅŸehir today. As a museum, the museum house, which can be visited every day of the week except Mondays, between official business hours, also gives important information about the style of life in the period with its interior design.
description.de:

AtatÃ¼rk, der den UnabhÃ¤ngigkeitskrieg begann, um die besetzten Gebiete des Osmanischen Reiches zu retten und dem Volk eine vÃ¶llig unabhÃ¤ngige Verwaltungsform zu geben, unternimmt viele vorbereitende Schritte, um die Grundlagen fÃ¼r diesen Krieg zu legen. Der Sivas-Kongress, das letzte vom Land organisierte Vorkriegstreffen, bei dem die fÃ¼hrenden Soldaten, KÃ¼nstler und Wissenschaftler zusammenkamen, ist der wichtigste dieser Schritte.

AtatÃ¼rk, der nach dem letzten Treffen des Sivas-Kongresses nach Ankara zurÃ¼ckkehren wollte, damit die tÃ¼rkische Nation eine vÃ¶llig unabhÃ¤ngige Verwaltungsform erreichen konnte, blieb vom 22. bis 23. Dezember 1919 in diesem Haus. Von groÃŸer architektonischer Bedeutung ist auch das Haus, in dem AtatÃ¼rk wohnte, der seine Route durch NevÅŸehir fÃ¼hrte, um die Heiligkeit von HacÄ±bektaÅŸ-Ä± Veli zu besuchen.

Dieses Haus, das prÃ¤chtigste unter den Lehmziegel- und Ziegelmaterialien des 19. Jahrhunderts, ist eines der schlichtesten und elegantesten Beispiele des osmanischen Zivilarchitekturstils. Das GebÃ¤ude, das 2001 vom Ministerium fÃ¼r Kultur und Tourismus restauriert wurde, ist heute eines der meistbesuchten Werke von NevÅŸehir. Als Museum gibt das Museumshaus, das auÃŸer montags jeden Tag der Woche besichtigt werden kann, mit seiner Innenausstattung wichtige Informationen Ã¼ber den Lebensstil dieser Zeit.

description.en:
MuÄŸla's tourist destinations in Marmaris in a very dominant point of the same name is another location of the castle. Marmaris Castle, which attracts attention with its views, promises an impressive ambience during the evening as well as during the day.


The date of construction of the castle is not clear, but it is thought that it dates back to Ionian rule in the region, hence it was built around 1000 BC. It is recorded that it was renewed in the time of Alexander the Great and maintained its importance throughout the centuries that followed. It is also known that it was renewed under the conquest plans for Rhodes Island during the time of the Ottoman Empire.


It is among the information that it was a target for French cannons in World War II. The castle, which was not used for tourism in Marmaris until the 1970s, has been a museum and sightseeing area since 1991 after extensive restoration.


Marmaris Castle has a total of 18 rooms. Ethnographic, artistic and archaeological exhibition areas are available in its indoor locations. The castle area, including a fountain, is one of the most important cultural structures that offers a variety of photographic riches, especially its landscape.

description.en:
It would not be wrong to say the land of fountains for Erzurum. Fountains, one of the common examples of water architecture, have been made in many places in the focus of providing hygiene and needs within the scope of the city's zoning activities. 

As a result of the importance given to water structures, fountains have an important place among the heritage left by the Ottoman Empire in Erzurum. In this context, one of the prominent fountains in the city is the Hollow Fountain, which was made at the beginning of the 20th century. 

The fountain, which was built as a block in the wall, is quite different from its first state as a result of the damages and accompanying repairs that have been going on for about a century. The fountain has a small slot that has been opened for the placement of the water cup and has a single lullaby where the groundwater flows. The lule can be summarized as a stone or metal fountain-shaped object, usually when the water comes out. 

The width of Hollow Fountain, which has a height of about 1 and a half meters, wide about 1 meter and 30 centimeters. This history-heirloom fountain, which is small but has a great service of its own, cools with its running water even decades later.

description.en:
One of the most important natural wonders of Bursa, SadaÄŸ Canyon and Hot Springs attract local people to Orhaneli throughout the year. Orhaneli district is generally known as a mountainous district and is about 60 kilometers from the city center. Located 6 kilometers south of the district, the canyon is one of the two largest canyons in the city. This place is particularly popular with local tourists.


Located in the area, the village bears the same name as the canyon. The main entrance section of the canyon begins about two kilometers outside the village. The water line here can be considered as a starting point. Walking distance takes an average of one and a half hours. At certain points, you will encounter rocky areas around 60 meters as you move towards the canyon. SadaÄŸ Creek will meet you on this road. You'll have to cross the stream to keep going. Plant and environmental regulations on the road have been successfully concluded. The presence of spa facilities opened in this area speeds up the regulation of the environment. There is now a vehicular path that will allow you to reach the canyon to the inland points. This paved road, which is bumpy from time to time, ends with an entrance added by the Directorate of Forestry.


There is a bathhouse in SadaÄŸ Canyon dating back to BC. This bath was built by the Roman Emperor Hadrian in dedication to his wife. The bath is surrounded by stone walls. Today, this bath is still intact. The 60-degree water simmering in the immediately opposite section of the creek is today included in the scope of the thermal plant. The large track between the canyon and the bathhouse is approximately two kilometers in length. This area is supported by various wooden bridges and ladders. This allows visitors to navigate the canyon more safely. After a little bit past the rock bath, you will encounter an impressive waterfall.
description.de:
Der SadaÄŸ Canyon und die heiÃŸen Quellen, eines der wichtigsten Naturwunder von Bursa, ziehen das ganze Jahr Ã¼ber Einheimische nach Orhaneli. Der Bezirk Orhaneli ist allgemein als Bergbezirk bekannt und liegt etwa 60 Kilometer vom Stadtzentrum entfernt. Der 6 Kilometer sÃ¼dlich des Bezirks gelegene Canyon ist auch einer der beiden grÃ¶ÃŸten Canyons der Stadt. Dieser Ort ist besonders beliebt bei einheimischen Touristen.

Das Dorf in der Region hat den gleichen Namen wie der Canyon. Der Haupteingang des Canyons beginnt ungefÃ¤hr zwei Kilometer auÃŸerhalb des Dorfes. Der Wasserdamm kann hier als Ausgangspunkt angesehen werden. Der FuÃŸgÃ¤ngerweg betrÃ¤gt durchschnittlich eineinhalb Stunden. Auf dem Weg in Richtung Canyon stoÃŸen Sie an bestimmten Stellen auf felsige Gebiete in einer HÃ¶he von etwa 60 Metern. SadaÄŸ Bach wird Sie auf dieser StraÃŸe begrÃ¼ÃŸen. Sie mÃ¼ssen den Bach Ã¼bergehen, um Ihren Weg fortzusetzen. Die Einrichtung und Landschaftsgestaltung auf der StraÃŸe wurde erfolgreich abgeschlossen. Das Vorhandensein von Thermalbad-Einrichtungen in diesem Bereich beschleunigt die Landschaftsgestaltung. Derzeit gibt es eine Fahrzeugroute, mit der Sie den Canyon zu den inneren Punkten erreichen kÃ¶nnen. Diese AsphaltstraÃŸe, die von Zeit zu Zeit auf und ab geht, endet mit einem Eingang, der von der ForstbehÃ¶rde hinzugefÃ¼gt wurde.

Im Sadag Canyon gibt es ein tÃ¼rkisches Bad vor dem Bad. Dieses Bad wurde vom rÃ¶mischen Kaiser Hadrian zu Ehren seiner Frau gebaut. Die Umgebung des Bades ist von Steinmauern umgeben. Dieses Bad ist bis heute stark. 60 Grad Wasser, das direkt Ã¼ber dem Bach brodelt, gehÃ¶ren heute zum Umfang der thermischen Anlage. Die groÃŸe Strecke zwischen dem Canyon und dem Bad ist ungefÃ¤hr zwei Kilometer lang. Dieser Bereich wird von verschiedenen HolzbrÃ¼cken und Treppen getragen. Auf diese Weise kÃ¶nnen Besucher sicherer durch den Canyon spazieren. Nachdem Sie das Felsenbad hinter sich haben, sehen Sie einen beeindruckenden Wasserfall.

description.en:
The Tomb of ZÃ¼beyde HanÄ±m, mother of the founder and first president of the Republic of Turkey, Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk, can be visited in the Karsiyaka District of Izmir. ZÃ¼beyde HanÄ±m, who was born in 1857 in the city of Thessaloniki on the borders of present-day Greece, died in 1923 in Izmir at the age of 66.

Located in a park on the street of the same name, the tomb has a very high spiritual importance, and is in the form of a monument that was designated by AtatÃ¼rk himself with a photograph of ZÃ¼beyde HanÄ±m.

ZÃ¼beyde HanÄ±m's tomb, built in 1940, is a first-degree site. In this respect, the arrangement of the mosque next to it, the expansion of the area around the tomb, the provision of lighting and the maintenance of the official ceremonial place were carried out. In addition, tea garden and playgrounds were built with the aim of more intensive families to come.

The spiritual area, which includes security personnel, is visited every day of the year by a large number of local and foreign tourists.

description.en:
Cultural and archaeological artifacts collected in 1965 at urgup District Public Library are exhibited in the museum building, which was completed in 1971 as a result of the need in the region. 

In the museum, which welcomes visitors with a very sophisticated look dedicated to ancient buildings, the interior is extremely simple. With many works on display in the showcase, various vehicles for production, such as the carpet counter semantics on the open, can also be seen at various points. 

Various ceramics from the prehistoric period, which dates back 10,000 years, from the B.C. to the vicinity of urgup; The region includes hittite, phrygian, Roman and Byzantine empire-era items, pot-snatched from terracotta, medals, coins, sculptures and many more cultural elements. The museum also attracts water-related fossils related to the region, formerly an inland sea, in the museum, which includes fossils of mammoths, an extinct animal species dating back 10 million years.

Seljuk and Ottoman ethnographic pieces stand out within the scope of the museum, which has a rich collection. Handcrafts, clothes, ornaments, various weapons, seals, weavings, manuscript books, edicts, lamps, hookahs can be examined closely. The museum has different visiting hours in two periods: summer and winter, and the closing is 19:00 in the summer months when the intensity increases. 

Located in the city center of Nevsehir, the museum awaits all cultural and history enthusiasts from 7 to 70.

description.en:
In Bursa, which was the capital of the first stages of the Ottoman Empire, as of the 14th century, architectural activities were given great importance. As a result of this situation, the Khans Region, which is the scene of the first examples of a rich cultural tradition, was built on a total area of 450 thousand square meters in the 14th century.


The construction of the complex, also known as the Khanlar District or Grand Bazaar, as a result of the construction work carried out in a large area, together with many new architectural works in the early Ottoman period, had a positive effect on the commercial development of the city. The Khanlar Region of Bursa, which managed to pass its name with its commercial progress along with the most important developments of the time in the history books, thus meets a lot of visitors even today.


Emir Khan, Old New Khan, Deserted Inn, Geyve Inn, Ipek Inn, Koza Inn with different names in the region, today just as hundreds of years ago, hosting many shops is designed as a complex. Today, the region is heavily visited by local and foreign tourists, especially textile products and various goods are sold.


It should be noted that the Grand Bazaar is one of the landmarks of Bursa. Sahaflar, quilters, sandÄ±kÃ§Ä±lar(ark makers) and many other bazaars referred by different names are almost a reflection of the traditional commercial life of today in the place where you travel hundreds of years ago, you wake up to the feeling of shopping. The Khanlar District & Grand Bazaar, which has been known to survive many negative events in the history of Bursa-including earthquakes and large fires - was rebuilt in 1960 as a multi-storey, not a single storey, unlike its original plan.
description.de:
In Bursa, der Hauptstadt zu Beginn des Osmanischen Reiches, wurde ab dem 14. Jahrhundert groÃŸen Wert auf architektonische AktivitÃ¤ten gelegt. In der Stadt, in der die ersten Beispiele einer reichen kulturellen Tradition zu sehen sind, wurde im 14. Jahrhundert auf einer GesamtflÃ¤che von 450.000 Quadratmetern der Hanlar-Bezirk fÃ¼r das GeschÃ¤ftsleben errichtet.


Der Bau des Komplexes, der auch als Hanlar-Bezirk oder GroÃŸer Bazaar bekannt ist, als Ergebnis der Bauarbeiten, die in den ersten Perioden, als das Osmanische Reich dominierte, in einem weiten Bereich zusammen mit vielen architektonischen Neubauten durchgefÃ¼hrt wurden, wirkte sich sehr positiv auf die wirtschaftliche Entwicklung der Stadt aus. Der Bezirk Hanlar in Bursa, der es mit seinem kommerziellen Fortschritt und den wichtigsten Entwicklungen der Zeit geschafft hat, seinen Namen in den GeschichtsbÃ¼chern zu finden, begrÃ¼ÃŸt daher auch heute noch eine ganze Reihe von Besuchern.


Mit seinen Abschnitten mit verschiedenen Namen wie Emir Khan, Alter Yeni Khan, IssÄ±z Khan, Geyve Khan, Ä°pek Khan, Koza Khan ist der Bezirk Hanlar als Komplex konzipiert, in dem sich wie vor Hunderten von Jahren viele GeschÃ¤fte befinden. Heute werden in der Region Textilprodukte und verschiedene Waren verkauft, die von einheimischen und auslÃ¤ndischen Touristen ausgiebig besucht werden.


Es sei darauf hingewiesen, dass der GroÃŸe Bazaar eines der Wahrzeichen von Bursa ist. Mit seinen Bazaaren, die in Antiquar, Steppdeckenhersteller, Truhenhersteller und vielem mehr bekannt sind, wird das GefÃ¼hl des Einkaufens auf Hunderten von Jahren in dem Ort geweckt, der das traditionelle GeschÃ¤ftsleben widerspiegelt. Der Hanlar-Bezirk und der GroÃŸe Bazaar, die durch viele negative Ereignisse wie Erdbeben und GroÃŸbrÃ¤nde, die die Geschichte von Bursa durchlaufen haben, Ã¼berlebt haben, wurden 1960 eher als mehrstÃ¶ckig als einstÃ¶ckig umgebaut.

description.en:
One of the historical values of Bursa surprised by its atmosphere is the Sulphurous Covered Bazaar. The 15th century structure, which is located in the oldest section of the large-scale bazaar, today houses more than 100 shops. It admires travellers with its historical texture and eye-catching shops in the centre of jewellery.


The Sulphurous Covered Bazaar, known in historical documents as the Long Bazaar, is becoming more and more interested with its shops adjacent to the Inns, which are listed in different concepts. The source of the interest, along with the diversity presented, is the main factors in its place on the UNESCO World Heritage list. Quilters, shoemakers, furniture makers and a lot of jewelry shops can be visited in the historical bazaar, which has survived to the present day.


The Sulphurous Covered Bazaar, where small breaks can be given during sightseeing and shopping, is one of the prominent places of business life in Bursa. The historic site continues to attract tourists from all over the city as well as domestic and international.

Die Hauptfaktoren sind die Tatsache, dass es in die Liste des UNESCO-Weltkulturerbes aufgenommen wurde, zusammen mit der Sorte, die als Quelle des Interesses angegeben wird, das es erhÃ¤lt. SteppdeckenhÃ¤ndler, Schuhmacher, MÃ¶belhersteller und viele Juweliere kÃ¶nnen auf dem historischen Bazaar besichtigt werden, der bis heute erhalten geblieben ist.


Der Ã¼berdachte Bazaar von KÃ¼kÃ¼rtlÃ¼, wo es Ess- und Trinkgelegenheiten gibt, an denen beim Besichtigen und Einkaufen kleine Pausen eingelegt werden kÃ¶nnen, ist einer der wichtigsten Orte des GeschÃ¤ftslebens in Bursa.
