description.en:
The Altindag District of Ankara is one of the areas shown as the temple of historical mosques in Anatolia. Surrounded by many mosques, Ahi Yakup Mosque is located on Selman-I Farisi Street in HacÄ± Bayram District, where the residents of the district worship peacefully with its modest architecture. It is an interesting structure, built on the sloping terrain and has a height of over one meter, because it is entered by climbing stairs.

When the structural features of the mosque are examined, it can be stated that the rectangular plan was made with mudbrick plaster on a stone basis and that its roof was covered with tile. The mosque,which its year of construction known, was completed in 1392. The person who built it is Ahi Yakup, son of Ahi Ã‡elebi. The mosque's characteristic mihrab remains of importance, though it has been altered after some repairs.

It is located close to Haji Bayram Mosque, one of the most important mosques in the region. It is also located in the middle of the Roman Hammam  and Ankara Castle. In general, it is located in an area of numerous historical monuments, including the Temple of Augustus. It is recommended to visit with both spiritual and historical significance.

description.de:
Murat Pasha Mosque, which creates integrity with all the other architectural artifacts around it and makes feel as if going around in a complex, has been defying time since 1573.

The mosque built in 1573 by Kuyucu Murat Pasha, one of the Sultan II. Selimâ€™s Pasha, in Ottoman Empire. It takes the name of the founder. The tomb of Nene Hatun, which is right next to it, the Tomb of Ahmediye Madrasah and the mosque, which forms a complete integrity with the bath, makes people feel as if they are wandering around the complex.

The work, which is one of the most well-known and most visited religious structures of Erzurum, is also very important for the religious tourism of the city. Murat Pasha Mosque, which is one of the most frequented places in the city by all local and foreign tourists, especially in terms of ease of transportation in the center of the city, also affects those who see it with its imposing beauty in the classical Ottoman period architectural style.

Each corner of the mosque, decorated with the art of 'mukarnas' decoration consisting of geometric shapes, smells art. Murat Pasha Mosque, which evokes the feeling that you are passing through a door that opens to the 16th century at the entrance, also amazes itself with its decorations made with the most beautiful tone of turquoise in it.

description.en:
Today the building known as Lala Åahin Pasha Children's Library is essentially a very old madrasa building. This building was built in the 14th century by Rumeli Governor Lala Åahin Pasha. The historical madrasa, which continues to serve in the field of education until after the Republic, is converted into a children's library by Bursa Metropolitan Municipality. Unfortunately, the historical madrasa remains in ruins for a long time before this decision is made. The Institution of Lovers of Antiquities, in 1969, step in this situation and provides the repair of the madrasa. The second restoration takes place 40 years from now. An important businessman living in Bursa provides financial resources for this restoration. Bursa Metropolitan Municipality, which recently owned the property rights of the building, performs the last maintenance work and opens the children's library.


Although a short time after its opening, students from the schools operating in Bursa are brought here in groups. It is stated that the building preferred for the library, which is located exactly on KavaklÄ± Street, was built with war booty in time. In the construction of the building, brick materials as well as stones called kefeki draw attention. It is reminiscent of Seljuk madrasa in terms of its plan. The entrance section is seen to be marble embedded. From this section you can switch to the covered area. An arch separating the dome and the vault can be mentioned. The ancient column-titled marbles in this area are taken from a Byzantine structure of that period.


The conversion of this historical madrasa into a children's library corresponds to the year 2012. The building, which houses the library, will undergo five major repairs in total. The restoration, especially in 1968, played a major role in achieving its present condition. The most important feature of the madrasa building is that it is the first Turkish work made in the city of Bursa.
description.de:
Das GebÃ¤ude, das heute als Lala Åahin Pasha Kinderbibliothek bekannt ist, ist im Wesentlichen ein altes Medresse-GebÃ¤ude. Dieses GebÃ¤ude wurde im 14. Jahrhundert von Rumelien Generalgouverneur Lala Åahin Pasha erbaut. Die historische Medresse, die bis nach der Republik im Bildungsbereich tÃ¤tig ist, wird von der Stadtverwaltung Bursa in eine Kinderbibliothek umgewandelt. Leider bleibt die historische Medresse lange Zeit in TrÃ¼mmern, bevor diese Entscheidung getroffen wird. Die AntikenbehÃ¶rde hat diese Situation 1969 aufgegriffen und die Medresse restauriert. Die zweite Restaurierung erfolgt in 40 Jahren. Ein wichtiger GeschÃ¤ftsmann in Bursa stellt finanzielle Mittel fÃ¼r diese Restaurierung bereit. Die Stadtgemeinde Bursa, die kÃ¼rzlich die Eigentumsrechte an dem GebÃ¤ude hatte, fÃ¼hrt die letzten Wartungsarbeiten durch und erÃ¶ffnet die Kinderbibliothek.

Obwohl es eine kurze Zeit seit seiner ErÃ¶ffnung ist, werden SchÃ¼ler, die an Schulen in Bursa studieren, in Gruppen hierher gebracht. Es wird berichtet, dass das fÃ¼r die Bibliothek in der KavaklÄ±-StraÃŸe bevorzugte GebÃ¤ude rechtzeitig mit Kriegsbeute gebaut wurde. Beim Bau des GebÃ¤udes ziehen die als Kefeki bezeichneten Steineâ€‹â€‹ebenso die Aufmerksamkeit auf sich wie die Ziegelmaterialien. In Bezug auf den Plan erinnert es die seldschukische Medresse. Es ist zu sehen, dass der Eingangsbereich einen Marmorrahmen hat. In diesem Abschnitt kÃ¶nnen Sie zum abgedeckten Bereich gehen. Ein Bogen, der Kuppel und GewÃ¶lbe trennt, kann erwÃ¤hnt werden. Die Marmoren mit antiken SÃ¤ulenÃ¼berschriften in diesem Bereich wurden zu dieser Zeit einer byzantinischen Struktur entnommen.

Die Umwandlung dieser historischen Medresse in eine Kinderbibliothek entspricht 2012. Das GebÃ¤ude, in dem sich die Bibliothek befindet, wird insgesamt fÃ¼nf Mal repariert. Die Reparatur, insbesondere im Jahr 1968, hat in ihrem gegenwÃ¤rtigen Zustand eine wichtige Rolle gespielt. Das wichtigste Merkmal des Medresse-GebÃ¤udes ist, dass es das erste tÃ¼rkische Werk in Bursa ist.

description.en:
Many historical baths in Bursa have reached successfully so far. One of these baths, II.Murat Hamam, is also known by names such as Haji Hamza or Municipal Hamam.


It is not known exactly by whom and when II.Murat Hamam was built. However, research indicates that the bathhouse was built in the early 16th century. The women's section is just north of the bath. The standoff section is located in the eastern section. This area is seen to be square planned. When you turn your direction towards the west of II.Murat Hamam, you may encounter the warmth and seclusion sections. The men's section is positioned in the south division. It can be observed that the four-pointed rooms in the male section are covered by a dome. In the middle part of the temperature of this area, a naval stone draws attention.


In the masonry sections of the main structure, a mixture of stone and brick materials was used. Only cut stones are placed in the corner sections. The door of the women's section is bounded by marble and lintels. Reflecting traces of Ottoman architecture II. Murat Bath belongs to the class of double baths. The historic site, which has recently undergone restoration, continues to serve as its original state. Today, however, only a certain part of the structure is suitable to serve as a bathhouse.


II. Murat Bath is also located in a large complex. Therefore, visitors come across a large building community. The madrasa building is located just east of the historic Bath. The bath is small in general. This place is very poorly maintained for a certain period and even functions as an iron casting workshop. Thanks to the restoration carried out by the Osmangazi Municipality in 2010, the hamam gains its original identity to a large extent. ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ TalaÅŸ, the operator of the bath, has been making efforts to keep the historic site alive since 1968.
description.de:
Es ist zu sehen, dass viele historische BÃ¤der in Bursa bis heute erfolgreich erreicht haben. Das Wasserbad vom II.Murat , eines dieser BÃ¤der, ist auch unter Namen wie Haci Hamza oder Gemeindewasserbad bekannt.

Es ist nicht genau bekannt, von wem und wann das Wasserbad vom II.Murat gebaut wurde. Trotzdem deuten Untersuchungen darauf hin, dass das Bad zu Beginn des 16. Jahrhunderts gebaut wurde. Die Frauenabteilung befindet sich auf der Nordseite des Badehauses. Der kalte Teil befindet sich im Ã¶stlichen Teil. Es ist zu sehen, dass dieser Bereich einen quadratischen Grundriss hat. Wenn Sie sich nach Westen von Wasserbad vom II.Murat drehen, kÃ¶nnen WÃ¤rme- und Privatzimmer auftreten. Die Herrenabteilung befindet sich im SÃ¼dbereich. Es ist zu beobachten, dass die viereckigen RÃ¤ume im MÃ¤nnerbereich mit einer Kuppel bedeckt sind. Im mittleren Teil des WÃ¤rmezimmers zieht ein Marmorstein zum Waschen die Aufmerksamkeit auf sich.

In den Wandabschnitten des HauptgebÃ¤udes wurden Materialien aus Stein und Ziegelmischung verwendet. In den Eckabschnitten werden nur geschnittene Steine â€‹â€‹verwendet. Die TÃ¼r der Frauenabteilung ist von Marmor und Sturz eingefasst. Das Wasserbad vom II.Murat, das Spuren osmanischer Architektur widerspiegelt, gehÃ¶rt zur Klasse der DoppelbÃ¤der. Der historische Ort, der kÃ¼rzlich restauriert wurde, dient weiterhin in seiner ursprÃ¼nglichen Form. Heute ist jedoch nur ein bestimmter Teil des GebÃ¤udes als Bad geeignet.

Das Wasserbad vom II.Murat befindet sich ebenfalls in einem groÃŸen Komplex. Daher treffen die Besucher hier auf eine groÃŸe Baugemeinschaft. Das Medresse-GebÃ¤ude befindet sich im Ã¶stlichen Teil des historischen Bades. Das Bad ist in der Regel klein. Dieser Ort bleibt fÃ¼r eine gewisse Zeit vernachlÃ¤ssigt und fungiert sogar als Eisengusswerkstatt. Dank der Restaurierung durch die Gemeinde Osmangazi im Jahr 2010 hat das Bad seine ursprÃ¼ngliche IdentitÃ¤t weitgehend erlangt. Der Besitzer des Badehauses, ÅÃ¼krÃ¼ TalaÅŸ, bemÃ¼ht sich seit 1968, den historischen Ort am Leben zu erhalten.

description.en:
The most beautiful aspect of Kars architecture is that it is formed by the combination of Armenian, Russian and Ottoman architectural styles. The Bookkeeping Building, which survived from the 1800s, is one of the most beautiful architectural works left by the Russians in Turkey.

As a result of the war between the Ottoman Empire and Russia in 1877-1878, the city of Kars was dominated by the Russians. Russians, who have been working feverishly to change the architectural planning of the city they have captured for 40 years, leave many very magnificent works in today's Turkey.

Built as a theatre hall in the late 1800s, the Bookkeeping Building is one of the most beautiful examples of Russians in baltic architectural style. The so-called Baltic architectural style begins in the Netherlands in the 18th century. This style, which was quickly loved and adopted by the Russians, also wants to be applied to the city of Kars. Built by bringing the best architects and engineers of the Netherlands, the building was restored in 1938 and started to be used as the Bookkeeping Building.

Today, the bookkeeping building of the State of the Republic of Turkey is one of the most popular buildings of Kars with its architectural beauty and its stance that amazes those who see it.
description.de:
Das Beste an der Kars-Architektur ist, dass sie aus armenischen, russischen und osmanischen Baustilen besteht. Das FinanzamtgebÃ¤ude aus dem Jahr 1800 ist heute eines der schÃ¶nsten BaudenkmÃ¤ler, das von den Russen der TÃ¼rkei verlassen wurde.

Infolge des Krieges zwischen dem Osmanischen Reich und Russland zwischen 1877 und 1878 geriet die Stadt Kars unter die Herrschaft der Russen. Die Russen haben 40 Jahre lang die architektonische Planung der Stadt, die sie erobert haben, mit einer fleiÃŸigen Arbeit vollkommen verÃ¤ndert und haben der heutigen TÃ¼rkei prachtvolle Werke Ã¼berlassen.

Das im spÃ¤ten 19. Jahrhundert als Theatersaal erbaute FinanzamtgebÃ¤ude ist eines der schÃ¶nsten Beispiele fÃ¼r Russen im baltischen Baustil. Der erwÃ¤hnte baltische Baustil beginnt in den Niederlanden im 18. Jahrhundert. Dieser Stil, der von den Russen in kurzer Zeit geliebt und angenommen wurde, will auch auf die Stadt Kars Ã¼bertragen werden. Das GebÃ¤ude, das von den besten Architekten und Ingenieuren der Niederlande erbaut wurde, wurde 1938 restauriert und als FinanzamtgebÃ¤ude genutzt.

Heute ist das FinanzamtgebÃ¤ude immernoch die architektonische SchÃ¶nheit der TÃ¼rkischen Republik und ist eine der beliebtesten Werke in Kars, das die Besucher mit ihrer Haltung fasziniert.

OsmanlÄ± bahÃ§esinde TÃ¼rk tarihinden gÃ¼nÃ¼mÃ¼ze taÅŸÄ±nmÄ±ÅŸ gÃ¶rsel zarafet, zen bahÃ§esinde uzak doÄŸunun mistik bitkileri, su bitkileri bahÃ§esinde apayrÄ± bir estetik ÅŸÃ¶lenin sÃ¶z konusu olduÄŸu Botanik BahÃ§eâ€™de, gÃ¼zelliÄŸe yapÄ±lan vurgularÄ±n yanÄ± sÄ±ra tÄ±bbi ve endemik bitkiler de dikkat Ã§eker. description.en:
Being one of the most authentic cities in Turkey, Gaziantep's Botanical Garden, founded in 2009, is a natural treasure intertwined with nature in the center of the city.

The Botanical Garden is home to many different types of plants from Turkey and the world as well as Gaziantep's plant presence in the wide area. In this way, it is aimed that visitors can recognize the presence of plants on a global scale while creating the gene source of plants. In this context, certain trainings are arranged for primary, secondary and higher education students by the municipality of Gaziantep.

In the garden, plants such as species, genera and fatherland are introduced at the required scale. The garden, which is full of plants depicted with many informative labels, also preserves and reproduces some endangered species. In fact, this process is among the primary objectives of the Botanical Garden.

The Botanical Garden, where every shade of green comes together with the most beautiful harmonies, is among the places where local and foreign tourists in Gaziantep feel the most intertwined with nature and want to take a photograph the most. This garden, which is known to take away the visitors of the Rose Garden, has a place in the permanent memory with its fragrances from the essences of even the most beautiful and most expensive perfumes. You know, because the smell is the last thing that's forgotten in human memory.

In the Botanical Garden, where there is a different aesthetic feast in the garden of water plants and mystic plants of the Far East and in the garden of zen, the visual grace carried from Turkish history to the present day in the Ottoman garden draws attention to beauty as well as medicinal and endemic plants. However, the Japanese Garden in the area also offers its guests a unique experience in a different concept.

description.en:
HisarbaÅŸÄ± District, located in the Milas region of Mugla, is home to an extremely important khan. Ã‡Ã¶llÃ¼oÄŸlu Khan, which continues to welcome domestic and foreign visitors throughout the year, stands out as one of the oldest places in Milas. It is known that the khan was built by Abdul Aziz Agha in 1720. During the construction process of this special and historical place, both rubble stones and reused stones are used extensively.


Ã‡Ã¶llÃ¼oÄŸlu Khan has a rectangular plan. Consisting of two floors in total, The khan offers examples of Ottoman architecture. The structure, which is unfortunately ruined today, hopes to be among the major stops for Milas sightseeing tours again.


Looking at the journey of the khan, only 20 years after it was built, it is seen that it was dedicated to a Madrasa located near the Agha mosque. The ground floor of the khan serves as a shelter for animals, while the upper floor is reserved for passengers. This is the case in general in other Khans in the Ottoman Empire. The khan has the potential to meet the expectations of the passengers who came to stay at the time. The roof section of the structure is covered with corrugated tiles. Today it is integrated with both the Belen Mosque and the Milas Arasta, so to speak. Therefore, visitors to the khan have the chance to witness these two historical sites. Arastan(ottoman bazaar) is thought to have been built directly connected to the khan. At least that's what the predictions are about. There is no conclusive information to support this.


Although the place is located in the center of the city, it has preserved its texture and architectural structure to at least a certain extent. The entrance point of Ã‡Ã¶llÃ¼oÄŸlu Khan is on the north side. It consists of an arched structure. The historic khan occupies a total area of one thousand 50 square meters. Despite its splendid appearance, the khanhas been somewhat neglected recently.

description.en:
Kugulu Park, which is one of the first places that comes to mind when it is called Ankara, is located exactly in KavaklÄ±dere neighborhood. The park is also close to Tunali Hilmi Street and has a large pool. This pool contains cute swans and geese. Therefore, this pool in the park is always of interest to especially children. Kugulu Park is a symbolic and classical place for Ankara residents. The interesting black swans found here are known to have been given as gifts by China. These swans are given to the Turkish delegation during an official visit to the city of Beijing earlier. Black swans are the largest color in Kugulu Park. You can witness the swans that gave the park its name from quite close range.

In the entrance section of Kugulu Park, there is a statue which was inaugurated in 2006. Tunali Hilmi, a Turkish politician, is used as a figure in this statue. In the other area of the park, there is another statue called â€˜the kissersâ€™. Children's play areas at Kugulu Park make this place even more attractive for families. On the other hand, you can use the cafeteria in the park for your basic needs. Kugulu Park has boards where you can get detailed information about bird species. A total of 24 bird species are found within this area. On the other hand, when you come to the park; you may encounter tree species such as Poplar, Sycamore or Judas tree.

This area consists of an area of Poplar before Kugulu Park was built. Ankara Municipality converted this land into a park in 1958. In early periods, the park does not receive much attention from the public. A comprehensive arrangement made in later periods changes the fate of the park in an instant. Kugulu Park, which has suddenly become one of the most popular social areas of Ankara, has an easy reach due to its location.

description.en:
Is located within the boundaries of Bursa II. Murat mausoleum is included in the area known as Muradiye mausoleum. So when you come to visit this shrine, you may encounter many coffins.

Firstly, the structure giving the name regarding of II. Murat, we should mention that he is the only ruler in the Ottoman Empire who left the Sultanate of his own will. In the meantime, according to the inscription on the door of the tomb, this place was built by Fatih Sultan Mehmet. As it is known, he is the son of II.Murat. According to the information in the same inscription, the mausoleum was built in 1451. In fact, it is passed on that it was built by the will of II.Murat himself.

Two rows of brick and rubble stone sequences were used in the structure that houses the Tomb. The dome section is left open. This was also part of II.Murat's will. The window in the eastern section of the II.Murat Mausoleum is converted into a door. In later periods, a new structure is added to this area. In this area, crates belonging to II.Murat's children are found. The upper section of the marble crate is covered with soil. II.Murat Mausoleum is located in the central part of the complex. It is also in the neighbouring state with the mosque, which is located within the building community. To enter the tomb, a marble iwan is passed through. The wooden eaves stand out as a rather impressive-looking detail. There are various geometric decorations in the immediate vicinity of the stars.The Tomb of II.Murat has a square plan. Each edge measures approximately 13 meters.

This tomb belonging to II.Murat, The Last Sultan buried in the city of Bursa, attracts the attention of local visitors throughout the year. II.Murat stands out as a sultan who does not like showing off in general. The structure of this shrine also reflects this understanding significantly. Although he was born in Amasya, he came to Bursa with his father to receive Palace education. It makes very important contributions to both art and cultural life in Bursa.
description.de:
Das Grab vom II. Murat, das sich innerhalb der Grenzen von Bursa befindet, gehÃ¶rt zur Region der Muradiye-GrÃ¤ber. Wenn Sie dieses Grab besuchen, kÃ¶nnen Sie daher auf viele Sarkophage stoÃŸen.

ZunÃ¤chst sollten wir Ã¼ber den II. Murat erwÃ¤hnen, der dem GebÃ¤ude seinen Namen gab, dass er der einzige Herrscher im Osmanischen Reich war, der das Sultanat mit seinem Willen verlieÃŸ. Ãœbrigens wurde dieser Ort laut Inschrift an der TÃ¼r des Grabes von Fatih Sultan Mehmet erbaut. Bekanntlich ist er der Sohn vom II. Murat. Nach Angaben in derselben Inschrift wurde das Grab 1451 erbaut. Es wird sogar behauptet, dass Murat sein Wille war.

Das GebÃ¤ude, in dem sich das Grab befindet, besteht aus zwei Reihen von Ziegeln und Schutt. Der Kuppelabschnitt bleibt offen. Dies ist auch ein Teil von Murats Testament. Das Fenster im Ã¶stlichen Teil des Grabes vom II. Murat wird in eine TÃ¼r umgewandelt. In den folgenden ZeitrÃ¤umen wird diesem Bereich eine neue Struktur hinzugefÃ¼gt. In dieser Gegend gibt es Sarkophage von den Kindern vom II. Murat. Der obere Teil des Marmorsarkophags ist mit Erde bedeckt. Das Grab vom II. Murat befindet sich im zentralen Teil des Komplexes. Es ist auch neben der Moschee in der Baugemeinde hier. Es wird durch einen Marmor-Iwan gefÃ¼hrt, um das Grab zu betreten. Die hÃ¶lzernen Traufe zeichnen sich durch ein Detail aus, das sehr beeindruckend aussieht. In unmittelbarer NÃ¤he der Sterne befinden sich verschiedene geometrische Ornamente. Das Grab vom II. Murat hat einen quadratischen Grundriss. Jede Kante wird auf ungefÃ¤hr 13 Metern gemessen.

Dieses Mausoleum, das dem II. Murat gehÃ¶rt, dem letzten in der Stadt Bursa begrabenen Sultan, zieht das ganze Jahr Ã¼ber die Aufmerksamkeit der lokalen Besucher auf sich. Der II. Murat sticht als Sultan hervor, der es nicht mochte, generell zu Ã¼bertrieben zu leben. Die Struktur dieses Grabes spiegelt dieses VerstÃ¤ndnis ebenfalls erheblich wider. Obwohl er in Amasya geboren wurde, kam er mit seinem Vater nach Bursa, um eine Palastausbildung zu erhalten. Es leistet sehr wichtige BeitrÃ¤ge zum Kunst- und Kulturleben in Bursa.

description.en:
<html>AltÄ±nbeÅŸik cave, which is located within the borders of Ibradi, one of the districts of Antalya city and is very close to ÃœrÃ¼nlÃ¼ KÃ¶yÃ¼, is also intertwined with the National Park.

Although there is misleading information about this, it is possible to go to the cave by car. In order to visit AltÄ±nbeÅŸik cave during working hours, you must enter through the main gate in the bridge section of the National Park.

A distance of about four kilometers is located between the village and the cave. You come to the area to experience this adrenaline-filled journey as well as to visit the cave. This is a very exciting way, especially for those with fear of heights. On the way to the cave, â€˜houses with buttonsâ€™ unique to Ibrali district are seen. AltÄ±nbeÅŸik cave is known as the largest underground lake in Turkey. When thought with its arms, the size of the cave is 2,200 meters. This of course only refers to the achievable part.

The entrance part of the cave meets its visitors with a 125-foot lake. The depth of the lake rises to levels of 15 meters. In the middle, there is a large block of rock and this is  a kind of bridge. In the last part of the lake, there is a steep travertine 44 meters long. Immediately afterwards, the cave continues through three separate branches. Investigations in the cave have taken place up to a stream reaching a height of eight meters. The cave is suitable for visiting only certain periods of the year. During the winter and spring seasons, the cave is closed to visitors. This place is completely filled with water during off-limits. This causes the cave to close.

AltÄ±nbeÅŸik cave is located at an altitude of 450 meters from the sea. The cave was discovered by Doctor Temujin Aygen in 1966. The interior of the cave was unearthed thanks to the work done by the Japanese and Czech teams in those years. To reach the region, Manavgat Big Waterfall Road or Konya Manavgat highway may be preferred.
</html>

description.en:
<html>Behramkale, located within the borders of Ã‡anakkale, is a very special village created during the Ottoman period. The main thing that makes this place so special is that it is a very old settlement. Looking towards the sea from the place we can also refer as the ancient city, it is noticeable that the settlement in Behramkale Village is on the opposite side.

Certain parts of the village are located within the walls of the ancient city. This allows the village to be visited by more people. Today only around 150 households live in Behramkale village. It has been protected as a site since thirty years. Therefore, building within the village area is prohibited. The houses in the village are very old and architecturally characteristic. This ensures that the existing texture is preserved.

Although it is forbidden to build new buildings, it is possible to restore existing houses. It is possible to find houses in the village that largely reflect the intricacies of stonework. The narrow streets of the village, adorned with these harka houses, are very pleasant to wander and take photographs. In addition, the people of the village are extremely warm towards the visitors. With the popularization of the village, numerous hotel and hostel options are created. Most of the houses are scenic and largely reflect the historic texture.

The ancient city of Assos is also located right at the top of the village. You can reach here if you walk up the hill covered with stones. In fact, when you walk through the door, you are first greeted by the famous temple of Athena. On the hill leading to the ruins, the villagers sell their products on the stalls left and right. Many village products, from home tarhanas(soup with dried yoghurt) to olive oil, from laces to shawls, are of great interest in this area. The village of Behramkale also has a mosque and a bridge dating from the Ottoman era. Especially The HÃ¼davendigar mosque, built by Ä±.Murat, draws attention with the pictures of the galleys in it.</html>
description.de:
Behramkale, innerhalb der Grenzen von Ã‡anakkale gelegen, ist ein ganz besonderes Dorf, das wÃ¤hrend der osmanischen Zeit gegrÃ¼ndet wurde. Der Hauptfaktor, der diesen Ort so besonders macht, ist, dass es sich um eine sehr alte Siedlung handelt. Bei einem Blick auf das Meer von einer so genannten antiken Stadt aus bemerkt man, dass sich die Siedlung im Dorf Behramkale auf der gegenÃ¼berliegenden Seite befindet.

Bestimmte Teile des Dorfes befinden sich innerhalb der Mauern der antiken Stadt. Dadurch kann das Dorf von mehr Menschen besucht werden. Heute leben im Dorf Behramkale nur noch rund 150 Haushalte. Es steht seit 30 Jahren als Schutzgebiet unter Schutz. Daher ist es verboten, GebÃ¤ude im Dorfgebiet zu bauen. Die HÃ¤user im Dorf sind sehr alt und architektonisch charakteristisch. Diese Situation stellt sicher, dass das vorhandene Gewebe erhalten bleibt.

Obwohl der Bau neuer GebÃ¤ude verboten ist, kÃ¶nnen bestehende HÃ¤user restauriert werden. Es ist mÃ¶glich, auf HÃ¤user zu stoÃŸen, die hauptsÃ¤chlich die Feinheiten der Steinmetzarbeit in DorfhÃ¤usern widerspiegeln. Es ist Ã¤uÃŸerst angenehm, durch die engen Gassen des Dorfes zu spazieren, die mit diesen Harka-HÃ¤usern geschmÃ¼ckt sind, und Fotos zu machen. DarÃ¼ber hinaus sind die Dorfbewohner den Besuchern gegenÃ¼ber sehr herzlich. Mit der Popularisierung des Dorfes entstehen viele Hotel- und PensionsmÃ¶glichkeiten. Die meisten HÃ¤user haben Aussicht und spiegeln weitgehend die historische Struktur wider.

Die antike Stadt Assos befindet sich ebenfalls oben im Dorf. Sie kÃ¶nnen hier ankommen, wenn Sie den mit Steinen bedeckten Hang gehen. Wenn Sie die TÃ¼r betreten, heiÃŸt Sie der berÃ¼hmte Athena-Tempel zuerst willkommen. Die Dorfbewohner verkaufen ihre Produkte am linken und rechten Stand am Hang, der zu den Ruinen fÃ¼hrt. Viele dÃ¶rfliche Produkte, von heimischen Tarhanas bis zu OlivenÃ¶len, von Spitzen bis zu TÃ¼chern, ziehen in diesem Bereich groÃŸe Aufmerksamkeit auf sich. Das Dorf Behramkale hat auch eine Moschee und eine BrÃ¼cke aus der osmanischen Zeit. Besonders die von Murat I. erbaute HÃ¼davendigar-Moschee fÃ¤llt mit den darin befindlichen Galeerenbildern auf.

description.en:
Ibrikli Church,which is famous for its nature, religious structures and historical monuments. is one of the oldest places of worship in Artvin.


It is difficult to get detailed information about Ibrikli Church. Due to the architectural features of the structure, It is estimated to belong to the Middle Ages period. There is no inscription of the church, which is thought to belong to the period when the Bagrats dominated the region. For this reason, there is no exact date on which it was built, by whom it was built or when it was actively used. After the Muslimisation of the region, the structure is hardly used. Today it is sadly in a state of ruin. However, it is possible to examine the structure in detail.


Only a few houses are located in the neighborhood where the church is located. The church in the south of the neighborhood is surrounded by meadows. Hidden among the trees, the structure has a free cross plan structure. The Church of Ibrikli, which has a roof with two chamfered cross arms, has a hoop with conical cones. The pulley body has round-arched windows. These windows are rectangular in shape and have a total of four. The main entrance of the church is in the western section. The church has two separate sections independent of each other. Naos, which is a real place other than the tonose covered space welcomes you.


The dome, which measures approximately 4.50 meters by 4.40 meters, attracts attention with its pandantive transitions. The arms located right next to the Naos are kept short. The most beautiful and remarkable part of the church is considered frescoed decorations. In the Naos section, very nice decorations stand out between the floor and the attic. Apart from the figures of the Saints, the quotations from the scriptures are combined with decorations dominated by a formidable craftsmanship.There are mainly brown and green colors in the foreground. Of course, these decorations will be greatly degraded until today. The church takes its name from the village to which it is attached.

description.en:
The Mevlevihane Foundation Museum, which was brought to life by explaining what mevlevism was and how its philosophy came to be until today, can be seen a postcard of Gaziantep from a spiritual point of view.

Mevlevihanes are characteristic and original structures of Anatolian geography. In this context, an old building society in Åahinbey, the famous District of Gaziantep with its historical structures, is a means of transferring a tekke (islamic monastery) belonging to Mevlevi sect to future generations in the form of a museum. Mevlevihane Foundation Museum, which is situated among the cultural and authentic values of the city, also contributes deeply to the recognition of this culture by local and foreign tourists.

As part of the museum, mannequins made of wax are equipped with authentic clothes on them and items reflecting the period around them. The museum, whose historical texture is quite striking, has designed scenes where the eyes cannot be taken, and the realism in these scenes is quite impressive. It deserves praise for its delicately designed decor and artistic design promise.

The presence of historical items is remarkable in the museum, where the experiences with emphasis on the period are exhibited together with various items. The spiritual atmosphere is also at a high level throughout the structure. However, the museum, which has a natural lighting and stands out with its high dome, promises visual discoveries in general and attracts attention with its large courtyard.

description.en:
<html>AyanÄ±s castle is built  by the most reformist King of the Kingdom of Urartu, Rusa II. After its construction is completed, the name Rusahinili-Eiduru-kai, which means 'the city of Rusa, opposite the Mount Suphan', is given. The castle, which was completed in 672 BC, is being resurfaced with a quarter of a century of excavations.

The castle, which also holds the title of being the most preserved and most magnificent structure of the Urartu Kingdom, also inspires researchers. Excavations are still continued to surface  The Castle of AyanÄ±s today. In this excavation, the entrance gate of the castle, the monumental walls, its very large warehouse and many various locations are reached. However, the most important place is the Haldi Temple. This temple is also very important in terms of religion as well as the width that can encompass many groups of structures. The temple area, located right in the middle and highest area of the castle, is entered through a gate made of alabaster. The inscription at the entrance of this gate says that the temple was gifted to the God of Haldi by Rusa,the son of Argisti. 

Like we said that the excavation stake of Ayanis Castle has been going on for a quarter of a century... Archaeologists working to surface the castle reach thousands of artifacts in this process. Hundreds of other works, including seals, shields, spears and hundreds more in AyanÄ±s Castle, where egyptian blue color is frequently used, are counting down the days to be exhibited in the museum after the inspections. AyanÄ±s Castle is an opportunity that those who want to witness history should not miss... 
</html>

<html>AyanÄ±s Burg wurde von dem reformistischsten KÃ¶nig des KÃ¶nigreichs Urartu Rusa dem II. gebaut. Nach Abschluss des Baus heiÃŸt es Rusahinili-Eiduru-kai, was "Rusa-Stadt auf der anderen Seite des Berges Suphan" bedeutet. Die Burg, die 672 vor Christus fertiggestellt wurde, wird mit den viertel langen Ausgrabungsarbeiten wieder freigelegt.

Die Burg, die den Titel des geschÃ¼tztesten und prÃ¤chtigsten Bauwerks des KÃ¶nigreichs Urartu trÃ¤gt, inspiriert auch Forscher. Die Ausgrabungen von AyanÄ±s Burg werden heute noch fortgesetzt. Bei dieser Ausgrabung werden das Eingangstor der Burg, seine monumentalen Mauern, sein sehr groÃŸes Lagerhaus und viele andere Orte erreicht. 
Der wichtigste Ort ist jedoch der Haldi-Tempel. Dieser Tempel ist nicht nur breit genug, um viele GebÃ¤udegruppen aufzunehmen, sondern auch religiÃ¶s. In der Mitte der Burg und im hÃ¶chsten Bereich wird der Tempelbereich durch eine TÃ¼r aus Alabaster betreten. In der Inschrift am Eingang dieser TÃ¼r steht, dass der Tempel dem Gott von Haldi vom Sohn von Argishti, Rusa, geschenkt wurde.

Wie gesagt, die Ausgrabungen der Burg Ayanis dauern seit einem Vierteljahrhundert an. Die Siegel, Schilde, Speere und Hunderte von Artefakten, die in der AyanÄ±s Burg gefunden wurden, wo hÃ¤ufig die Ã¤gyptische blaue Farbe verwendet wird, zÃ¤hlen die Tage, die nach den Untersuchungen im Museum ausgestellt werden sollen. AyanÄ±s Burg ist eine Gelegenheit, die diejenigen, die Geschichte erleben wollen, nicht verpassen solltenâ€¦

description.en:
Trabzon is a city whose origins extend back thousands of years. The city, which runs along the Black Sea coast in eastern of Turkey, is also a regional attraction. It is also a pioneer with its dense population and social dynamics. 

The city's rich historical heritage is basically exhibited with historical buildings and museums. One of the highlights of this scope is undoubtedly the Trabzon Historical Museum. As its name suggests, the museum, which is based on the basis of shining a light on the history of the city, is located in ortahisar district, which is also home to many historical structures. 

Nearly 10,000 documents and photographs are on display within the scope of the museum. Postcards, countless examples of local media, historical documents, movies are leading at this point. One of the highlights of the museum is a wet signed letter by the Founder of the Republic of Turkey and the first President Mustafa Kemal Ataturk can be seen. 

Among the works exhibited in a historical house, it is necessary to open a separate bracket to the engravings of the pilgrims who have visited the city. In addition, films including images of Trabzon in the 1930s can be seen within the collection. 

Trabzon Historical Museum, where various written and visual documents can be examined in different concepts, is important for shining a light on the recent period of ancient history.
description.de:
Trabzon ist eine Stadt, deren UrsprÃ¼nge Jahrtausende zurÃ¼ckreichen. Die Stadt, die sich entlang der SchwarzmeerkÃ¼ste im Osten der TÃ¼rkei erstreckt, ist auch ein regionales Anziehungspunkt. Es hat eine fÃ¼hrende Position mit seiner dichten BevÃ¶lkerung und sozialen Dynamik.

Es ist zu sehen, dass das reiche historische Erbe der Stadt hauptsÃ¤chlich mit historischen GebÃ¤uden und Museen ausgestellt ist. Einer der kulturellen Werte, die in diesem Zusammenhang auffallen, ist zweifellos das Trabzon Geschichtsmuseum. Wie der Name schon sagt, befindet sich das Museum, das die Geschichte der Stadt beleuchtet, im Stadtteil Ortahisar, in dem sich auch viele historische GebÃ¤ude befinden.

Fast 10.000 Dokumente und Fotos werden im Museum ausgestellt. Ganz oben auf diesem Punkt stehen Postkarten, unzÃ¤hlige Beispiele der lokalen Presse, historische Dokumente und Filme. Einer der bekanntesten Werte im Museum ist, dass ein nass signierter Brief des GrÃ¼nders der tÃ¼rkischen Republik und des ersten PrÃ¤sidenten Mustafa Kemal AtatÃ¼rk zu sehen ist.

Unter den in einem historischen Haus ausgestellten Werken sind auch die Gravuren von Reisenden zu erwÃ¤hnen, die die Stadt besucht haben. DarÃ¼ber hinaus sind in der Sammlung auch Filme zu sehen, die Bilder von Trabzon aus den 1930er Jahren enthalten.

Das Trabzon Geschichtsmuseum, in dem verschiedene schriftliche und visuelle Dokumente in unterschiedlichen Konzepten untersucht werden kÃ¶nnen, ist wichtig, um die jÃ¼ngste Periode einer alten Geschichte zu beleuchten.

description.en:
<html>There are monument that have been standing in many cities of Turkey for centuries and have been the subject of legends. At this point, there is no doubt that the HÄ±dirbey Musa Tree in SamandaÄŸ district of Hatay is the subject of a more interesting rumor than many others. It's unbelievable, but this imposing tree is thought to be 3,000 years old. 

The famous story of The Tree of HÄ±dÄ±rbey Musa, one of the symbols of Hatay, has been spreading from ear to ear for generations and has survived to the present day. It is rumored that Musa thrust his wand where the tree is. The wand with the water of immortality, turns into a tree and grows, and has been living in full glory completely for 3,000 years since. 

It is not known whether it is true or a rumor, but the Tree of HÄ±dirbey Musa is a true visual feast with its enormous dimensions. The tree has a diameter of about 8 meters in its trunk, and its height is around 10 meters. Taken with its branches, it covers more than 1000 square meters of space. 

HÄ±dirbey Musa Tree, which has monumental tree status, is one of the most visited destinations of the city with its cafÃ© and unique beauty, which can be enjoyed in its shadow. 
In general, it can be stated that it is among the important sightseeing locations close to the Mediterranean. </html>
description.de:
<html>Seit Jahrhunderten stehen in vielen StÃ¤dten der TÃ¼rkei alte und denkmalige BÃ¤ume, die zu Legenden geworden sind. An dieser Stelle besteht kein Zweifel, dass der HÄ±dÄ±rbey Musa Baum im SamandaÄŸ-Viertel von Hatay interessanter erzÃ¤hlt wird als viele andere. Es ist unglaublich, aber dieser imposante Baum wird fÃ¼r dreitausend Jahre alt gehalten.

Die berÃ¼hmte Geschichte von HÄ±dÄ±rbey Musa Baum, eines der Symbole von Hatay, hat sich seit Generationen verbreitet und reicht bis heute. Der Legende nach legt Hz.Moses seinen Zauberstab an die Stelle, an der der Baum steht. Der Zauberstab mit dem unsterblichen Wasser wÃ¤chst zu einem Baum und lebt seit genau 3000 Jahren in seiner Pracht.

Es ist nicht bekannt, ob es wahr ist oder eine ErzÃ¤hlung, aber HÄ±dÄ±rbey Musa Baum ist ein echtes visuelles Fest mit seinen riesigen Dimensionen. Die HÃ¶he des Baumes, der einen Durchmesser von ca. 8 Metern hat, betrÃ¤gt ca. 10 Meter. Zusammen mit seinen Asten erstreckt es sich Ã¼ber eine FlÃ¤che von mehr als 1000 Quadratmetern.

Der HÄ±dÄ±rbey Musa-Baum, der den Status eines Denkmalbaums hat, gehÃ¶rt zu den meistbesuchten Orten in der Stadt. Hier kÃ¶nnen Sie in einem CafÃ© Tee und Kaffee trinken und die einzigartige SchÃ¶nheit genieÃŸen.
Es kann gesagt werden, dass es sich im Allgemeinen um einen der wichtigsten Reiseziele in der NÃ¤he des Mittelmeers handelt.</html>

description.en:
When you pass the village of Hisaronu in MuÄŸla a little further, you will be welcomed by a very special place called KayakÃ¶y. This place is often described as a â€˜Dream Villageâ€™. It is known that this village, where interesting houses lined up around the slope add colour, used to be a Greek settlement. The Greeks who lived here at that time developed themselves well, especially in the field of agriculture. They are therefore far from the idea of building houses on fertile land. The houses are mostly set in Rocky or gizzard areas. This is clearly reflected in the name of the village. The structure of the houses is the most important value that adds authenticity to the village in this sense.


Around 20 thousand people lived in the village until the beginning of 1920s. After the war of Independence, the Greeks living here have to emigrate because of the exchange. Christian communities have lived here regularly since the 1400s. Immigrants from Western Thrace are placed in KayakÃ¶y after the exchange. The former owners of the village who went to Greece call the new area they settled in Athens as â€˜Yeni MeÄŸriâ€™. New houses are built on the plains left by the Greeks.


Today the population of the village has decreased significantly despite this settlement. Despite this, the old houses left by the Greeks are carefully preserved. These houses are officially protected. KayakÃ¶y's name in those years is known asâ€™ Levissi'. There are 14 chapels in the village except for two separate churches, but these religious sites are unfortunately in ruins. Especially the churches named Katopanayi and Taksiyarhis suffer a great deal of damage. The doors of these churches are exhibited in Fethiye Museum. The Church of Panagia is in a relatively better condition today and is open to visitors. When you come to the village, you must go to the hill area to reach the chapels. From here it is possible to see SoÄŸuksu Bay as a whole.
